		<item>
		<title>What I&#039;ve learned</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=1076</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jessdeng08]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=1076</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As we've decided what our individual research topic proposals would be, we learned many strategies on how to search for readings on it. For example, my topic is: Blogging. I never knew we would learn about more research strategies that we've learned in the past three classes. While I was doing my research topic proposal, I only used Google. I never knew there was such thing as "Google Scholar" or "Google Advanced Search". While I was trying these two new websites, I noticed I've received more results on Blogging than on Standard Google. There were scholary articles, journals,

&nbsp;

- advanced internet searching
- searching library catalogs
- searching article databases

What have you learned in these classes thats new to you?

How do you see yourself using your new skills outside of our course?]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1076</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>

		<item>
		<title>research proposal </title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=917</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Rehana]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=917</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[My question for the research proposal is is facebook changing the nature of privacy? I choose this topic because, all most all of us familiar with facebook and at the same time it one of the most popular social networking website. All though the impact of facebook is tremendous, but b while not all are positive there problem as well benefits. The main focus point on my research paper is the privacy issues regarding facebook; also Im going to find out the negative and positives consequence of putting your personal information in facebook. I think that this is a really interesting topic, since most us have facebook account but we dont recognized the outcomes. It is true that the facebook is changing the nature of privacy because the luck of communication and having some capacity do whatever in your own. Sometime even your own word can be your biggest enemy, your personal information could split beyond the boundary and you could end up with hand of third party.]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Syllabus</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/syllabus/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 Aug 2010 21:42:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Maura Smale]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[LIB 1201 - Research &amp; Documentation for the Information Age

Fall 2010
Tue/Thu 10:00-11:15am
Room: <del datetime="2010-10-31T02:27:15+00:00">A540</del> A543 (Library)

Prof. Maura Smale
Email: <a href="mailto:msmale@citytech.cuny.edu">msmale@citytech.cuny.edu</a>
Phone: 718.260.5748
Office: <del datetime="2010-10-31T02:27:15+00:00">A539</del> A543B (Library)
Office Hours: Tue/Thu 11:15am-12:30pm and by appointment

<strong>Course Website: </strong><a href="../">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com</a>

<strong>Course Description</strong>
In this course we will explore issues in research and documentation for text (in print and online), images, sound, and multimedia. You will investigate where information comes from and how it is organized in both traditional and emerging media. We will examine the ethics of information use and determine how to critically evaluate sources. Throughout the course, you will create and present research and documentation projects using traditional and emerging media and technologies.

<strong>Course Goals</strong>
To introduce you to the theory and practice of research and documentation for all information and media, including:
<ul>
	<li>Cultural, economic and political factors that affect information and media</li>
	<li>The organization of information in multiple formats</li>
	<li>Developing methods for finding information that is relevant to you</li>
	<li>Critically evaluating information and its sources</li>
	<li>Copyright, fair use, and ethical use of information and media</li>
	<li>The role of documentation and citation in scholarly, professional, and public work</li>
</ul>

<strong>Learning Outcomes</strong>
For the successful completion of this course, you should be able to:
<ul>
	<li>Describe the ways that information is produced and organized in a variety of formats</li>
	<li>Create and articulate a relevant, manageable research topic for your assignments</li>
	<li>Successfully search for and acquire appropriate information about your research topic in a variety of media and formats</li>
	<li>Critically evaluate and select information sources for your assignments and projects</li>
	<li>Use information ethically and responsibly with an awareness of copyright and fair use</li>
	<li>Synthesize information on a topic from a variety of sources and present your analysis in writing and orally</li>
	<li>Collaborate with a group to complete, modify, and document a process online</li>
	<li>Apply documentation methods and citation styles appropriately in your own work</li>
</ul>

<strong>Course Policies</strong>

Contacting the professor:
Please speak with me if there is anything you find unclear about the readings or assignments, or if you have concerns about your work in the course. Email is the best way to contact me  I will respond within 48 hours (and usually sooner). I also hold regular office hours at 11:30am-12:30pm Tue/Thu and by appointment.

Attendance:
You are expected to attend every class during the course. The City Tech attendance policy allows a student to be absent during the semester without penalty for up to 3 class sessions. Additional absences will lower your grade in this course.

Lateness: 
Please be on time for class. Late students may miss important course material and can be disruptive to the rest of the class. Excessive lateness will lower your grade in this course.

Deadlines:
All assignments are due on the dates listed in the Course Schedule below. Failure to submit work on time will result in a lower grade for the assignment.

Etiquette:
Please be respectful of the opinions of others during class discussions and blog interactions. Please silence your cellphone during class, and do not text or IM unless requested to by the professor. Eating is not permitted in the library computer classroom, but you may bring a drink with a lid.

Plagiarism:
All assignments and work in this course must be your own, and you must give proper credit to any information or ideas that are the work of others. Please familiarize yourself with the college policy on plagiarism:

<blockquote>NYCCT Statement on Academic Integrity:
Students and all others who work with information, ideas, texts, images, music, inventions, and other intellectual property owe their audience and sources accuracy and honesty in using, crediting, and citing sources. As a community of intellectual and professional workers, the College recognizes its responsibility for providing instruction in information literacy and academic integrity, offering models of good practice, and responding vigilantly and appropriately to infractions of academic integrity. Accordingly, academic dishonesty is prohibited in The City University of New York and at New York City College of Technology and is punishable by penalties, including failing grades, suspension, and expulsion.</blockquote>

Further information (including penalties for plagiarism at City Tech) can be found in the Student Handbook: <a href="http://www.citytech.cuny.edu/files/students/handbook.pdf">http://www.citytech.cuny.edu/files/students/handbook.pdf</a>

<span style="text-decoration:underline;">Additional Resources for Students</span>:

The College Learning Centers offer tutoring and writing support in 2 locations: Atrium G18 and Voorhees 217. For more information: <a href="http://websupport2.citytech.cuny.edu/learningcenters/">http://websupport2.citytech.cuny.edu/learningcenters/</a>

To use a computer on campus visit one of the Computing Centers: <a href="http://cis.citytech.cuny.edu/SSLabs.htm">http://cis.citytech.cuny.edu/SSLabs.htm</a>

I hope that you will become very familiar with the City Tech Library during this course. For additional research support, please dont hesitate to visit the Reference Desk or the library website: <a href="http://library.citytech.cuny.edu/">http://library.citytech.cuny.edu</a>

<strong>Assignments and Grading</strong>

Your grade in this course will be based on:
<ul>
	<li>Class participation: 15%</li>
	<li>Blog posts/comments: 20%</li>
	<li>Research topic proposal: 5%</li>
	<li>Annotated bibliography: 10%</li>
	<li>Research paper - draft: 10%</li>
	<li>Research paper - final: 15%</li>
	<li>Online documentation project: 15%</li>
	<li>Class presentation: 10%</li>
</ul>

Participation in class discussions and in-class assignments:
You are expected to complete all readings/viewings and come to class prepared to discuss them. Please bring at least 1 question about the readings to <strong>every </strong>class. In-class activities will include developing research topics, formulating search strategies, evaluating information, etc.

Blog:
Short blog posts are required throughout the course. See deadlines in the course schedule (below), and details on the course blog (<a href="http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/blogging-guidelines/">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/blogging-guidelines/</a>).

Research topic proposal:
In consultation with the professor, choose a research topic relevant to the course and write a 100 word proposal. You will use this research topic for your annotated bibliography and research paper.

Annotated bibliography:
Select a minimum of 5 sources in a variety of media formats on your research topic and create an annotated bibliography (100 words minimum per source).

Research paper:
Write a research paper on your approved topic. Papers must be 5-8 pages in length (not including illustrations or References), typed, double-spaced. You are required to submit <strong>at least one draft</strong> of your paper before submitting the final version (see deadlines in the course schedule below).

Online documentation project:
In small groups assigned by the professor, students will build an online resource and collaboratively document their process.

Class presentation:
Each student group will give a 20 minute class presentation describing their online resource and presenting the finished online documentation project.

Full <a href="http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/assignments/">details and requirements for each assignment</a> will be discussed in class and posted to the course blog.

<strong>Required Textbook</strong>

Badke, W. B. (2008). Research strategies: Finding your way through the information fog. New York: iUniverse, Inc.

This text is available for less than $20 in the City Tech bookstore, and I strongly recommend that you purchase it. We will read almost the entire book in this class and it should also be useful to you for other courses that require research.

You can also buy it as an ebook (in PDF) for only $6 from the publisher's website: <a href="http://www.iuniverse.com/bookstore/BookDetail.aspx?BookId=SKU-000063139">http://www.iuniverse.com/bookstore/BookDetail.aspx?BookId=SKU-000063139</a>

The book is also on reserve in the library: CALL NUMBER: Z710 .B23 2008

Additional materials to read/view are assigned for each class, see Course Schedule (below). Most of these materials are available online (at no cost to you) in library databases or on the internet; the rest are on reserve in the library. Links to <a href="http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/readings/">materials available online</a> are posted on the course blog.

<strong>Recommended Reading</strong>

There are no assigned readings from these books, but you may find them helpful to consult during the course (they are on reserve in the library).

Devine, J., and Egger-Sider, F. (2009). Going beyond Google: The invisible web in learning and teaching. New York: Neal-Schuman Publishers, Inc.<br />
CALL NUMBER: ZA4237 .D4 2009

Discusses expert searching of "deep" web resources, may be useful for research on your paper/project topics.

Riedling, A. M. (2006). Learning to learn: A guide to becoming information literate in the 21st century. New York: Neal-Schuman Publishers, Inc.<br />
CALL NUMBER: ZA3075 .R54 2006

This book is similar to our textbook, and offers another set of guidelines for research and writing.

<strong>Course Schedule</strong>

All readings and assignments are due <strong>at the beginning of class</strong> on the date listed below. Please write down and bring at least one question about one of the readings to <strong>every</strong> class, and come to class prepared to discuss <strong>all</strong> of the day's assigned readings.

Thu 8/26:
Introduction to the course; sign up for course blog

<span style="text-decoration:underline;">The Information Landscape: Media and Production</span>

Tue 8/31:
Brief history of media; the lifecycle of information; traditional print media: journalism, academic/government/research agency publications
<em>Reading:</em> Read Badke Preface, Ch. 1 and Ch. 8
<em>Assignment:</em> Write one reading response blog post

Thu 9/2:
Digital text: online versions of print media, "born digital" content
<em>Reading:</em> Pavlik pp. 1-8, Harrington and Meade pp. 6-9
<em>Viewing:</em> Common Craft blogs and wikis videos
<em>Assignment:</em> Write one reading response blog post

Tue 9/7:
Alternative media: print (zines, pamphlets, etc.) and electronic (blogs, wikis, etc.)
<em>Reading:</em> Eland, Zine World, Wright (Part I only)
<em>Assignment:</em> Comment on at least one blog post

Thu 9/9:
NO CLASS OR OFFICE HOURS

Tue 9/14:
NO CLASS OR OFFICE HOURS (classes follow a Friday schedule)

Thu 9/16:
Non-text media: sound, images, multimedia
<em>Reading:</em> Pavlik pp. 79-84, Malitz, Elton
<em>Assignment:</em> Write one reading response blog post; comment on at least one blog post

Tue 9/21:
Web 2.0 and participatory media
<em>Reading:</em> Web 2.0 (Wikipedia), Baker
<em>Viewing: </em>Common Craft social media video
<em>Assignment:</em> Write one reading response blog post

<span style="text-decoration:underline;">Issues in Information and Media</span>

Thu 9/23:
Access: personal, institutional, digital divide
<em>Reading:</em> Martin Ch. 7
<em>Assignment:</em> Write one reading response blog post

Tue 9/28:
Preservation: paper, digital media, other formats, compatibility
<em>Reading:</em> Levi, Bee
<em>Assignment:</em> Comment on at least one blog post 

Thu 9/30:
Ethics: copyright, fair use, plagiarism, open access
<em>Reading:</em> Isserman, Center for Social Media sections "Code" and "Principles"
<em>Viewing:</em> Lessig, Faden
<em>Assignment:</em> Write one reading response blog post

<span style="text-decoration:underline;">How Information and Media Are Organized</span>

Tue 10/5:
Metadata: information about information, taxonomies, folksonomies
<em>Reading:</em> Badke Ch. 4, Dye
<em>Assignment</em>: Write one research journal blog post; comment on at least one blog post

Thu 10/7:
Search mechanics: what is a database, how does a search engine work
<em>Reading:</em> Badke Ch. 3, Liddy
<em>Assignment:</em> Comment on at least one blog post

Tue 10/12:
Metadata for non-text media; metadata challenges
<em>Reading:</em> Read: Goodin, Levinson
<em>Assignment:</em> Write one research journal blog post

<span style="text-decoration:underline;">Finding Information and Media</span>

Thu 10/14:
The research process: needs assessment, preliminary strategies, topic development
<em>Reading:</em> Badke Ch. 2
<em>Assignment:</em> Comment on at least one blog post

Tue 10/19:
The research process: refining a topic, creating search strategies
<em>Reading:</em> Badke Appendix 1 pp. 177-195, review Badke Ch. 3 pp. 34-41
<em>Assignment:</em> Write one research journal blog post

Thu 10/21:
Searching: internet
<em>Reading: </em>Badke Ch. 6 (all) and Ch. 7 pp. 122-124
<em>Viewing: </em>Common Craft web search strategies video
<strong>DUE: Research topic proposal</strong>

Tue 10/26:
Searching: library catalogs
<em>Reading:</em> Badke Ch. 5 pp. 71-76, Library of Congress Classification Outline
<em>Assignment:</em> Write one research journal blog post

Thu 10/28:
Searching: article databases
<em>Reading:</em> Badke Ch. 5 pp. 76-95
<em>Assignment:</em> Comment on at least one blog post

<span style="text-decoration:underline;">Using Information and Media</span>

Tue 11/2:
Evaluation of sources in any format: why to evaluate
<em>Reading:</em> Fister, Grimmelman
<em>Assignment:</em> Write one research journal blog post

Thu 11/4:
Evaluation of sources in any format: how to evaluate
<em>Reading:</em> UC Berkeley, Cornell
<strong>DUE: Annotated bibliography</strong>

Tue 11/9:
Writing an academic research paper
<em>Reading:</em> Badke Ch. 10 and Appendix 1 pp. 196-203
<em>Assignment:</em> Write one research journal blog post

Thu 11/11:
Rationale for documentation and citation
<em>Reading:</em> Read Hauptman pp. 7-13
<em>Assignment:</em> Comment on at least one blog post

Tue 11/16:
Documentation: standards, methods and styles for citing text and non-text media
<em>Reading:</em> Badke Ch. 9, browse Purdue OWLs APA and MLA Style sections
<strong>DUE: Research paper draft</strong>

Thu 11/18:
Documentation: standards, methods and styles for practices and processes
<em>Assignment:</em> Find one example of process documentation in any format, read it, and write one blog post in which you describe, summarize and critique it. Be prepared to discuss your example in class!

Tue 11/23:
Group project work

Thu 11/25:
NO CLASS  COLLEGE CLOSED (Happy Thanksgiving!)

Tue 11/30:
Documentation: practical applications
<em>Reading:</em> Edge, Robinson
<strong>DUE: Research paper final version</strong>

Thu 12/2:
Group project work

<span style="text-decoration:underline;">Presentation of Information and Looking to the Future</span>

Tue 12/7:
Future of information and media, wrapping up
<em>Viewing:</em> Sloan

Thu 12/9:
Group project work

Tue 12/14:
Student presentations

Thu 12/16:
Student presentations
<strong>DUE: Online documentation project</strong>

<strong>Want to print or save this page? Download it as a PDF:
<a href='http://lib1201fall2010.files.wordpress.com/2010/08/lib1201_fall2010_syllabus1.pdf'>LIB1201_Fall2010_Syllabus</a></strong>

		<item>
		<title>Readings</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/readings/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 Aug 2010 21:42:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Maura Smale]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[American Psychological Association. (2010). <em>Publication manual of the American Psychological Association</em>. 6<sup>th</sup> Ed. Washington, DC: American Psychological Association.
(in the library at the Reference Desk and on Reserve: call number BF76.7 .P83 2010)

American Psychological Association. (2007). <em>APA style guide to electronic references. </em> Washington, DC.
(in the library at the Reference Desk and on Reserve: call number PN171 .A63 2007)

Badke, W. B. (2008). <em>Research strategies: Finding your way through the information fog</em>. New York: iUniverse.
(in the library on Reserve: call number Z710 .B23 2008)

Baker, N. (2008, March 20). The charms of Wikipedia<em>. New York Review of Books 55</em>(4). <a href="http://www.nybooks.com/articles/21131">http://www.nybooks.com/articles/21131</a>

Bee, R. (2008). <a href="http://search.ebscohost.com.citytech.ezproxy.cuny.edu:2048/login.aspx?direct=true&amp;db=a9h&amp;AN=31426144&amp;site=ehost-live">The importance of preserving paper-based objects in a digital world</a><em>. Library Quarterly, 78,</em> 179-194.

Center for Social Media. (2008). <em>The code of best practices in fair use for media literacy education.</em> <a href="http://www.centerforsocialmedia.org/fair-use/related-materials/codes/code-best-practices-fair-use-media-literacy-education">http://www.centerforsocialmedia.org/fair-use/related-materials/codes/code-best-practices-fair-use-media-literacy-education</a>

Common Craft. (2007). <em>Blogs in plain English. </em><a href="http://www.commoncraft.com/blogs">http://www.commoncraft.com/blogs</a>

Common Craft. (2008). <em>Social media in plain English. </em><a href="http://www.commoncraft.com/socialmedia">http://www.commoncraft.com/socialmedia</a>

Common Craft. (2007). <em>Wikis in plain English. </em><a href="http://www.commoncraft.com/video-wikis-plain-english">http://www.commoncraft.com/video-wikis-plain-english</a>

Common Craft. (2008). <em>Web search strategies in plain English. </em><a href="http://www.commoncraft.com/search">http://www.commoncraft.com/search</a>

Cornell University Library. (2009). Critically analyzing information sources. <a href="http://www.library.cornell.edu/olinuris/ref/research/skill26.htm">http://www.library.cornell.edu/olinuris/ref/research/skill26.htm</a>

Dye, J. (2006). <a href="http://search.ebscohost.com.citytech.ezproxy.cuny.edu:2048/login.aspx?direct=true&amp;db=a9h&amp;AN=20221017&amp;site=ehost-live">Folksonomy: A game of high-tech (and high-stakes) tag</a>. <em>EContent, 29</em>(3), 38-43.

Edge, I.E. (2006). <a href="http://search.ebscohost.com.citytech.ezproxy.cuny.edu:2048/login.aspx?direct=true&amp;db=a9h&amp;AN=22843297&amp;site=ehost-live">Write it down! The importance of documentation.</a> <em>Tech Directions, 66</em>(3), 16-18.

Eland, T. (2004). Critical thinking, deviant knowledge and the alternative press. <em>Minnesota Association for Continuing Adult Education Update Newsletter, December, </em>4-6.
(available at <a href="http://www.minneapolis.edu/library/courses/infs1000/files/Readings/Critical%20Thinking%20Deviant%20Knowledge.pdf">http://www.minneapolis.edu/library/courses/infs1000/files/Readings/Critical%20Thinking%20Deviant%20Knowledge.pdf</a>)

Elton, S. (2009, August 29). <a href="http://www.lexisnexis.com.citytech.ezproxy.cuny.edu:2048/us/lnacademic/api/version1/sr?shr=t&amp;csi=5545&amp;sr=BYLINE(Serona+Elton)+AND+HLEAD(LOVE+FOR+LABELS)+AND+DATE+IS+August+29+2009">Love for labels</a>. <em>Billboard, 121</em>(34), 4.

Faden, E. (2007). <em>A fair(y) use tale.</em> <a href="http://dotsub.com/view/4918f3c8-8f04-4aa1-b300-39048dca6822">http://dotsub.com/view/4918f3c8-8f04-4aa1-b300-39048dca6822</a>

Fister, B. (2003). <a href="http://search.ebscohost.com.citytech.ezproxy.cuny.edu:2048/login.aspx?direct=true&amp;db=a9h&amp;AN=10358332&amp;site=ehost-live">The devil in the details: Media representation of ritual abuse and evaluation of sources.</a> <em>SIMILE: Studies in Media and Information Literacy Education, 3</em>(2), 1-14.

Goodin, D. (2007, January 8). Managing content in a rich-media world. <em>InfoWorld</em>. <a href="http://www.infoworld.com/d/developer-world/managing-content-in-rich-media-world-635?page=0,0">http://www.infoworld.com/d/developer-world/managing-content-in-rich-media-world-635?page=0,0</a>

Grimmelman, J. (2008/2009). The Google dilemma. <em>New York Law School Law Review, 53,</em> 939-950. <a href="http://works.bepress.com/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1018&amp;context=james_grimmelmann">http://works.bepress.com/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1018&amp;context=james_grimmelmann</a>

Harrington, M. and C. Meade. (2008). <em>read:write: Digital possibilities for literature.</em> Institute for the Future of the Book. <a href="http://www.futureofthebook.org.uk/ifbook%20ACE%20report_final.pdf">http://www.futureofthebook.org.uk/ifbook%20ACE%20report_final.pdf</a>

Hauptman, R. (2008). <em>Documentation. A history and critique of attribution, commentary, glosses, marginalia, notes, bibliographies, works-cited lists, and citation indexing and analysis.</em> Jefferson, NC: McFarland &amp; Company.
(in the library on Reserve: call number PN171 .F56 H38 2008)

Isserman, M. (2003, May 2). Plagiarism: a lie of the mind. <em>Chronicle of Higher Education, 49</em>(34), B12. <a href="http://chronicle.com.citytech.ezproxy.cuny.edu:2048/article/Plagiarism-a-Lie-of-the-Mind/23609/">http://chronicle.com/article/Plagiarism-a-Lie-of-the-Mind/23609/</a>

Lessig, L. (2007). Larry Lessig on laws that choke creativity. 
<a href="http://www.ted.com/talks/larry_lessig_says_the_law_is_strangling_creativity.html">http://www.ted.com/talks/larry_lessig_says_the_law_is_strangling_creativity.html</a>

Levi, Y. (2008). <a href="http://search.ebscohost.com.citytech.ezproxy.cuny.edu:2048/login.aspx?direct=true&amp;db=a9h&amp;AN=34459911&amp;site=ehost-live">Digital preservation: An ever-growing challenge</a>.<em> Information Today</em>,<em> 25</em>(8), 22.

Levinson, C. (2006). <a href="http://search.ebscohost.com.citytech.ezproxy.cuny.edu:2048/login.aspx?direct=true&amp;db=a9h&amp;AN=21425620&amp;site=ehost-live">Anthropology, taxonomies, and publishing</a>. <em>Online, 30</em>(4), 28-30.

Library of Congress. (n.d.). <em>Library of Congress Classification Outline.</em> <a href="http://www.loc.gov/catdir/cpso/lcco/">http://www.loc.gov/catdir/cpso/lcco/</a>

Liddy, E. (2001). <a href="http://search.ebscohost.com.citytech.ezproxy.cuny.edu:2048/login.aspx?direct=true&amp;db=a9h&amp;AN=4446940&amp;site=ehost-live">How a search engine works.</a> <em>Searcher, 9</em>(5), 39-45.

Malitz, D. (2007, October 11). Radiohead's 'Rainbows': Is free release a potential pot of gold? The Washington Post, C01. <a href="http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/10/10/AR2007101002442.html">http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/10/10/AR2007101002442.html</a>

Martin, B. (1998). The politics of research. In <em>Information liberation: Challenging the corruptions of information power.</em> London: Freedom Press
(available at: <a href="http://www.bmartin.cc/pubs/98il/il07.pdf">http://www.bmartin.cc/pubs/98il/il07.pdf</a>)

Pavlik, J. V. (2008). <em>Media in the digital age.</em> New York: Columbia University Press.
(in the library on Reserve: call number HM851 .P38 2008)

Purdue University Online Writing Lab (OWL) (2010). <em>APA Style.</em> <a href="http://owl.english.purdue.edu/owl/resource/560/01/">http://owl.english.purdue.edu/owl/resource/560/01/</a>

Purdue University Online Writing Lab (OWL) (2010). <em>MLA Style.</em> <a href="http://owl.english.purdue.edu/owl/resource/747/01/">http://owl.english.purdue.edu/owl/resource/747/01/</a>

Robinson, C. (2009). <a href="http://search.ebscohost.com.citytech.ezproxy.cuny.edu:2048/login.aspx?direct=true&amp;db=a9h&amp;AN=36560656&amp;site=ehost-live">Documentation dilemmas.</a><em> Journal for Quality &amp; Participation, 31</em>(4), 35-37.

Sloan, R. (2004). EPIC 2015  Museum of Media History. <a href="http://epic.makingithappen.co.uk/">http://epic.makingithappen.co.uk/</a>

UC Berkeley  Teaching Library Internet Workshops. (2010). Evaluating web pages: Techniques to apply and questions to ask. <a href="http://www.lib.berkeley.edu/TeachingLib/Guides/Internet/Evaluate.html">http://www.lib.berkeley.edu/TeachingLib/Guides/Internet/Evaluate.html</a>

Web 2.0. (2010, August 9). In <em>Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia</em>. <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Web_2.0">http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Web_2.0</a>

Wright, F. (1997). The history and characteristics of zines, Part I. <a href="http://www.zinebook.com/resource/wright1.html">http://www.zinebook.com/resource/wright1.html</a>

Zine World. (2007). Zines 101A quick guide to zines. <a href="http://www.undergroundpress.org/pdf/Zines101.pdf">http://www.undergroundpress.org/pdf/Zines101.pdf</a>

<strong>Want to print or save this page? Download it as a PDF:
<a href='http://lib1201fall2010.files.wordpress.com/2010/08/lib1201_fall2010_syllabus2.pdf'>LIB1201_Fall2010_Syllabus</a></strong>

		<item>
		<title>Blogging Guidelines</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/blogging-guidelines/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 Aug 2010 21:43:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Maura Smale]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In this course you are required to write a minimum of 20 posts of at least 100 words each for our class blog (though of course you're encouraged to write more!). Our blog will allow us to continue discussions outside of class, and I will participate along with you. You can also use your blog posts to explore ideas that you may wish to develop more fully in your research paper or documentation project.

You will write several types of blog posts during this course:

1. Reading response (posts from 8/31-9/30; see <a href="http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/syllabus/">syllabus</a> for details):
Write a blog post discussing one of the readings assigned for the class. Identify a topic or theme from the reading, briefly summarize it, and analyze it in relation to other readings and themes in the course. Does this reading raise any questions in your mind?

2. Research journal (posts from 10/5-11/11; see <a href="http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/syllabus/">syllabus</a> for details):
Write a blog post discussing and documenting your process and progress on the research paper for this course. I will give you a question or prompt for each of these posts -- if you miss class, check the course website for details (under Announcements).
<br /><del datetime="2010-10-04T11:40:18+00:00">You may write about any aspect of this process, for example: deciding on a research topic, finding sources, writing the proposal/annotated bibliography/paper, etc. What have you found difficult or frustrating about this process? What successful strategies have you used?</del>

3. Blog comment (throughout the semester; see <a href="http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/syllabus/">syllabus</a> for details):
Select a blog post by one of your classmates and write a response to her/his post. What other perspectives on this topic can you offer? How does the blog post connect to the course readings and themes?

If you include or discuss text, images, or multimedia in your blog posts that are not from the assigned readings, please cite your source. Source title, author, date, and URL (if it's a website) is sufficient for these posts. We will discuss citation styles in more detail as the course progresses.

Also, please give each of your blog posts one or more tags. We'll talk more about tags in class, but for now you can think of them as keywords. Try to pick a few words that describe the topic of your post.

Blog posts need not be written in the formal academic style you will use for your research paper, but please use proper spelling, grammar and punctuation when you blog.

<strong>How to Post on the Course Blog</strong>
<ol>
	<li>Go to <a href="../">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com</a>.  On the right navigation bar under "Meta" click "Login." Enter your username and password.</li><br />
	<li>Now you're on the Wordpress Dashboard. To post your      blog entry, click "Add New" under the "Posts" menu on the left navigation bar.</li><br />
	<li>On the Add New Post page you can enter a title for your post and then paste or type your blog post into the large field in      the middle of the screen.</li><br />
	<li>There are two ways to format posts: Visual or HTML. If you know HTML feel free to use it. Otherwise you may want to select Visualand use the buttons along the top of the field to add bold, italics, etc.</li><br />
	<li>Give your post one or more tags by entering them into the field under "Post Tags" on the right side of the Add New Post page.</li><br />
	<li>If you'd like to take a look at your post before publishing it live on the course blog, click the "Preview" button on the upper right side of the Add New Post page.</li><br />
	<li>When you're ready to publish your post to the blog for all to see, click the blue "Publish" button on the right side of the Add New Post page.</li><br />
	<li>To view the blog after publishing your post, click the blog's name at the top of the Add New Post page.</li>
</ol>

To post a comment on the blog, click the "Leave a Comment" link on any blog post.

For both blog posts and comments, I strongly suggest that you write in a word processor or text editor and paste the finished text into the Add New Post page or comment box.

Please let me know if you have any questions or run into any problems: <a href="mailto:msmale@citytech.cuny.edu">msmale@citytech.cuny.edu</a>

<strong>Grading</strong>:

Blog posts are worth 20% of your total course grade. I will email your blog grades to you at the beginning of each week for posts published the prior week.

Each blog post will be graded as follows: 

<table border="0" cellspacing="5" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><strong>Points</strong></td>
<td><strong>Rating</strong></td>
<td><strong>Characteristics of the Blog Post</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr valign="top">
<td>2</td>
<td>Excellent</td>
<td>
&#8226; The blog post is focused and relevant to the topic.
<br />&#8226; Post provides examples and explanations or analysis, and reflects in-depth engagement with the topic.
<br />&#8226; Sources are cited (if not from course readings).
<br />&#8226; Post is at least 100 words and has been given at least one tag.
<br />&#8226; Post is submitted by the beginning of class (on time).
</td>
</tr>
<tr valign="top">
<td>1</td>
<td>Competent</td>
<td>
&#8226; The post is mostly description or summary, without consideration of alternative perspectives, and few connections are made between ideas.
<br />&#8226; Post reflects passing engagement with the topic.
<br />&#8226; Sources (if not from course readings) are not cited.
<br />&#8226; Post is at least 100 words, but has not been given any tags.
<br />&#8226; Post is 1-2 days late.
</td>
</tr>
<tr valign="top">
<td>0</td>
<td>Insufficient</td>
<td>
&#8226; The blog post consists of one or two disconnected sentences, or no post was written for the assignment.
<br />&#8226; Post is less than 100 words and has not been given any tags.
<br />&#8226; Post is more than two days late.
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>

Adapted from:
Sample, Mark. (2009). <em>Pedagogy and the Class Blog</em>. Retrieved January 27, 2010, from SAMPLE REALITY Web site: <a href="http://www.samplereality.com/2009/08/14/pedagogy-and-the-class-blog/">http://www.samplereality.com/2009/08/14/pedagogy-and-the-class-blog/</a>; Schmitt, K.M., Behler, A., and E. Rimland. (2009). Blogging: Create an Online Community. In <i>Library Instruction Cookbook</i>, pp. 166-167. Chicago: ACRL.

<strong>Want to print or save this page? Download it as a PDF: <a href='http://lib1201fall2010.files.wordpress.com/2010/08/lib1201_blogging1.pdf'>LIB1201_Blogging</a></strong>

<hr />

<div align="center"><a rel="license" href="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/"><img alt="Creative Commons License" style="border-width:0;" src="http://i.creativecommons.org/l/by-nc-sa/3.0/88x31.png" /></a><br />This work is licensed under a <a rel="license" href="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/">Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License</a>.</div>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[default]]></wp:meta_value>

							</item>
		<item>
		<title>Assignments</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/assignments/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 Aug 2010 21:43:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Maura Smale]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Requirements, guidelines, and grading scales for each of the course's major assignments will be posted here as the semester progresses.

<p><a href="#bibliography">Annotated Bibliography</a> | <a href="#proposal">Research Topic Proposal</a></p>

<hr />

<a name="bibliography"></a><strong>Guidelines for the Annotated Bibliography</strong>
<strong>DUE:</strong> Thursday November 4th (at the <strong>beginning</strong> of class!)

The annotated bibliography is worth 10% of your total course grade. Bibliographies will be graded using the grading chart included below.

&#8226; Select a minimum of 5 (more than 5 is okay!) different sources of information on your topic, including:
&nbsp; &nbsp; - at least 2 news sources
&nbsp; &nbsp; - at least 2 scholarly sources
&nbsp; &nbsp; - at least 1 internet source

If you are unsure whether a source youd like to use meets one of these criteria, please ask me.

&#8226; Begin with the citation for each source, formatted using APA Style. For guidelines use the APA Style Guides in the library (see <a href="http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/readings/">readings</a> for call numbers), or the Purdue Online Writing Lab (OWL): <a href="http://owl.english.purdue.edu/owl/resource/560/01/">http://owl.english.purdue.edu/owl/resource/560/01/</a> 

&#8226; Underneath each citation, write an annotation for the source. Each annotation must be <strong>at least</strong> 100 words, though of course it may be longer.

&#8226; In your annotation, please <strong>summarize</strong> the source and provide a brief analysis of how the source <strong>relates</strong> to your research question.

&#8226; Please write in a formal academic style, no first person ("I") statements. Avoid excessive jargon, and do not use quotations from your sources.

&#8226; This guide to creating an annotated bibliography from the City Tech Library may be helpful: <a href="http://library.citytech.cuny.edu/research/subjectGuides/annotated/">http://library.citytech.cuny.edu/research/subjectGuides/annotated/</a> (though note that the citations in this guide use MLA Style  we are using APA Style). You may also wish to consult this guide from the Purdue OWL: <a href="http://owl.english.purdue.edu/owl/resource/614/1/">http://owl.english.purdue.edu/owl/resource/614/1/</a>

&#8226; Please type up your annotated bibliography as a word processing document and either a) email it to me or, b) print it out and bring it to class. Use a standard 12 point font with 1 inch margins. Annotations can be single-spaced.

&#8226; I'll grade your bibliography within a few days after you submit it, so you can use it while writing your research paper draft. Your research paper draft will be due on Tuesday November 16th.

As always, please ask me if you have any questions! Remember that my office hours are 11:15am-12:30pm Tuesdays and Thursdays (right after class), and am happy to make an appointment to meet with you at other times.

<a href='http://lib1201fall2010.files.wordpress.com/2010/08/lib1201_bibliography.pdf'>Download the guidelines and grading chart</a> for your annotated bibliography.

<hr />

<a name="proposal"></a><strong>Guidelines for Research Topic Proposal</strong>
<strong>DUE:</strong> Thursday October 21st (at the <strong>beginning</strong> of class!)

Your individual research project for this course is a series of writing assignments that lead up to a 5-8 page research paper: a research topic proposal, an annotated bibliography, a draft of the paper, and the final paper.

For your research topic proposal (worth 5% of your total course grade):

&#8226; Choose a research topic that is both: 1) relevant to the course content, and 2) interesting to you. Your topic may be something we have already discussed in class, or it may be on a subject we will discuss in the coming weeks.

&#8226; In your paper I will ask you to use a variety of different sources on your topic, including:
at least one news source
at least one internet source
at least one scholarly source

&#8226; It's best if you choose a topic that is discussed in both academic and popular sourcesplease ask me if you are unsure about your sources.

&#8226; Write a proposal presenting your paper topic. Your proposal must include your research question.

&#8226; Your proposal must be at least 100 words, though of course it may be longer.

&#8226; Please give considerable thought to whether your topic is focused enough to write about in 5-8 pages. We will also spend time in class discussing how to narrow your focus and decide upon a manageable research topic.

&#8226; Please either: a) type up your research proposal as a word processing document and email it to me or, b) print it out and bring it to class.

&#8226; I'll take a look at your topics and give you feedback fairly quickly. It's possible that your topic may need to be further refined, and I can meet with you or discuss over email.

&#8226; Your annotated bibliography is due two weeks after the proposal, on November 4th.

As always, please ask me if you have any questions! Remember that I have office hours 11:15-12:30 Tuesdays and Thursdays.

<a href='http://lib1201fall2010.files.wordpress.com/2010/08/lib1201_proposal.pdf'>Download the guidelines and grading chart</a> for your research proposal.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>18</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-08-09 21:43:22</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-08-09 21:43:22</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>assignments</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>4</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
								<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3452646]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
				<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key>_edit_lock</wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1287676506]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
				<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key>_wp_page_template</wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[default]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
								<wp:comment>
		<wp:comment_id>6</wp:comment_id>
		<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[hyeongi8309]]></wp:comment_author>
		<wp:comment_author_email>stay8309@gmail.com</wp:comment_author_email>
		<wp:comment_author_url>http://hyeongi8309.wordpress.com</wp:comment_author_url>
		<wp:comment_author_IP>76.15.184.43</wp:comment_author_IP>
		<wp:comment_date>2010-09-03 16:44:14</wp:comment_date>
		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-09-03 16:44:14</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[As an international student, I found myself troubled with the notion of plagarism. This was more of an internal conflict rather than something that actually surfaced. For some time, I was a senior student in South Korea. There, using and transcribing information from other scholarly articles when writing research papers was not an issue. The reason for this leniency is due to the fact that college students are not professional writers and as sdtudents, we should learn from others. However, the term copy does not simply mean that a student copies and pastes other people's ideas. Students must show his/her idea based on the information that he/she found. Students can copy the information as exmaples and explain ideas that already exist. However, they need to writer their own ideas and draw their own conflusions with the copied information. Students in Korea also need to indicate where the information came from but the way to copy from professional writing or scholarly articles definitely saves more time when writing research papers rather than changing the information into his/her own words. I believe that changing his/her words will help in undersatnding and absorbing the information well. However, as college students, we already know that if we do not understand, we cannot write out own ideas. I think the way of writing research papers differs in America and other countries. Yet the basic idea that the student needs to find their own ideas is the same anywhere in the world.]]></wp:comment_content>
		<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
		<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
		<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
		<wp:comment_user_id>15975243</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>

		<item>
		<title>About</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/about-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 10 Aug 2010 18:09:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Maura Smale]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This is the course website for LIB 1201 - Research &amp; Documentation for the Information Age, taught in the Fall 2010 semester by <a href="http://library.citytech.cuny.edu/about/faculty/bio/smale.php">Prof. Maura Smale</a> in the <a href="http://library.citytech.cuny.edu">Library Department</a> at <a href="http://www.citytech.cuny.edu">New York City College of Technology</a> of the <a href="http://www.cuny.edu">City University of New York</a>.

Header image credits: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/patrickgage/3738107746/">Patrick Gage</a>, <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/gesteves/149624341/">Guillermo Esteves</a>, <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/brook/33497104/">Robert Brook</a>, <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/travelinlibrarian/3212467447/">Travelin' Librarian</a>, and <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/bepster/119115268/">Beppie K.</a>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Welcome!</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/08/24/welcome/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 24 Aug 2010 19:04:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Maura Smale]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Announcements]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="announcements"><![CDATA[Announcements]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[blog]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="blog"><![CDATA[blog]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=1</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Hello LIB 1201 students, and welcome to our course website. Im looking forward to our reading, writing, and discussion this semester. During our first class this week well get everyone signed up on the site as blog authors, and well take it from there.

<div align="center"><a href="http://lib1201fall2010.files.wordpress.com/2010/08/1156638214_3bc9e3726d.jpg"><img src="http://lib1201fall2010.files.wordpress.com/2010/08/1156638214_3bc9e3726d.jpg?w=300" alt="" title="1156638214_3bc9e3726d" width="300" height="225" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-85" /></a></div>

--Prof Smale

(Photo credit: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/romulusnr/1156638214/">Keith Tyler</a>)]]></content:encoded>

		<title>LIB1201_Fall2010_Syllabus</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/readings/lib1201_fall2010_syllabus-3/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Aug 2010 20:49:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Maura Smale]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.files.wordpress.com/2010/08/lib1201_fall2010_syllabus2.pdf</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>99</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-08-25 20:49:29</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-08-25 20:49:29</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

		<title>Chapter 1 Post</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/08/30/chapter-1-post/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Aug 2010 11:15:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jessdeng08]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Books]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="books"><![CDATA[Books]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Magazines]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="magazines"><![CDATA[Magazines]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Publishing]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="publishing"><![CDATA[Publishing]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=125</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In Chapter 1, part 1.5 "Information Today - The State Of the Art" briefly explain in detail about some of the main sources of information we use today. Everyday we use books, journals, magazines, the internet, web 2.0, government and corporate documents to gather information we may need for any kind of writing we may be doing or for knowledge. Book publishing is a continuing process and as we are part of a society that depends on technology a lot, many publishers are publishing electronic versions of books. Information and sources are everywhere no matter where we turn but it is up to you to use your own better judgment to decide whether the sources that are available to us , if they're reliable and relevant.]]></content:encoded>

See you in class tomorrow! I'm looking forward to reading your blog posts.

--Prof Smale]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Reasearch Strategies</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/08/31/reasearch-strategies/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 31 Aug 2010 03:20:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ckottenbach]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Research? Where do you start?]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="research-where-do-you-start"><![CDATA[Research? Where do you start?]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=124</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I am now entering the ethernet and can't wait to learn strategies of the 21st century! Badke is starting me on my way. The first chapter deals with discernment of legitimate source material which I found useful. With billions of information at anyones's fingertips, a wealth of knowledge and opinions is just ready for the taking.From books, to journals, newspapers, mega search engines andmyriad data bases to absorb, a research project certainly can be a lengthy process just to peal away layers of information to start the process rolling.

Years ago when I was in high school we had no internet. We sat in a library for hours,bleary eyed, dry eyed, surrounded by whatever books and journals the library had to offer - period. Now it looks like I'll need a GPS, my bifocals and a lap top computer, with a Bloody Mary sitting inmy ownkitchen deciphering abstracts from journals and a foreword and introduction from a hundred or so e-books of my choosing.

Subject Headings

Subclass T

T58.5-58.

Information technology]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Blog Response 1</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/08/31/blog-response-1/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 31 Aug 2010 05:29:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ssira9018]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Research]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="research"><![CDATA[Research]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Research Stratergies]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="research-stratergies"><![CDATA[Research Stratergies]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Response]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="response"><![CDATA[Response]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Techniques]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="techniques"><![CDATA[Techniques]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=120</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[At times <em>learning how to read for research </em>is something I find complicated because I cant determine what information is more important than the other. <strong>Chapter eight</strong> addressed this problem with solutions and introduced different techniques, of learning how to read for research. A technique I found quite interesting is-being <em>ruthless</em>- going straight to what youre looking for and eliminating extraneous information. In books this can easily be done by looking at the title. And by looking at the subtitle we can determine the books main focus. The preface and forward is a preview to the reader-on what the author will discuss in the upcoming chapters. The table of contents and index is where you evaluate and examine what you need and what to omit. Chapter eight also suggests to ask <em>constant questions</em> about the book such as How does this authors beliefs compare or contrast with other things youve been reading?(pg140). A question I always ask myself is is the information 100% accurate? This is very important because sometimes even the most reliable sources seem to make mistakes. For example, my brothers high school history textbook (we would define this as a scholarly text, the information in this textbook has been "supposedly" verified by 100 professionals in the field of history) labeled two prime ministers names wrong (they were switched). Now imagine thousands of students in America being educated through this same textbook. In the bigger picture, its always good to find more then one reliable source for accuracy.

Another helpful technique everyone should be practicing is <strong>note-taking</strong>. Note-taking can be difficult, especially when the lecturer or pages of an encyclopedia seem to go on forever. But its actually quite easy. One way to ace this is to <strong>create a simple outline and to make sure you answer your research question</strong>.

My question: How do we research information through encyclopedias, do we follow the same format as we would for a book?

-SSIRA9018

]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[That's a great example about your brother's textbook. We can explore using encyclopedias for research in the coming weeks. Usually the entries in an encyclopedia are short enough that each topic is essentially its own chapter, but it can be useful to scan over the subtitles first to get a sense of the topic.]]></wp:comment_content>

		<item>
		<title>Knowledge is power </title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/08/31/knowledge-is-power/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 31 Aug 2010 06:11:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[lynn905]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[key]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="key"><![CDATA[key]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=147</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Hi m y name is Lynn Jean; Let me take you deep into the deepest depths of a well know book written by one of the greatest writers who had ever wrote tips on helping, and encourage viewers in planing work studies and many more through a world of information. This man is named William B. Badke the author of <span style="text-decoration:underline;">Research Strategies</span>. In his wonderful book of strategies, viewers being to learn the fine art of the importances of information; its vases knowledge of how it set up to be any amazing source that help mankind in living life to the fullest, and survive it challenges. Take the time and think back to a place of how information was send out, before technology and writing was ever formed, do you had a picture, good hold on to it!

<a href="http://lib1201fall2010.files.wordpress.com/2010/08/index_banner-pict.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-148" title="index_banner pict" src="http://lib1201fall2010.files.wordpress.com/2010/08/index_banner-pict.jpg?w=300" alt="" width="300" height="104" /></a>

Yes! You got it was by word of mouth were this information were pass down from generation to generation, now image if information never got out. They were starving, because no knew what plants were edible and what were deadly (Badke 2). This quote shows that many people have starve to death because of the lack of information of which food source were good for the picking or deadly to devour. Ive learned the importance of information and how its used in many way not just to survive, but to advance all of mankind make it; what it is today has we know it.

In todays society we have made major discoveries by Entering the World Wide Web, giving us the abilities to communicate with each other in many forms and send information fast, more memorable and easier making knowledge more attain to the world. One approach to preservation of electronic data has been to rethink copy right for electronic document (Badke 8).This quote shows us that do to world-wide web document we were able to be saved and persevered show the organ of where it came from and making it valid for proof that it is real. In Mr. William B. Badke author of Research Strategies, He showed his reader how to understand the concept of information that it not just paragraph of word and etc. it goes fewer then that tell viewers that Information = Knowledge: and If Knowledge is power and power is the key. I leave you with this question what is information?

By: Lynn Jean

-Key]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Textbook update</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/08/31/textbook-update/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 31 Aug 2010 18:52:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Maura Smale]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Announcements]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="announcements"><![CDATA[Announcements]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Badke]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="badke"><![CDATA[Badke]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[course reading]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="course-reading"><![CDATA[course reading]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=162</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I went down to the bookstore to check in on your textbook. They are ordering new copies which should be available on Thursday. We'll be taking a break from Badke for the next month so I strongly encourage you to pick up the book before we get back to it in early October. You may also want to pick up a used copy from Amazon.com, Half.com or other online bookstores.

I also checked on the <a href="http://www.iuniverse.com/bookstore/BookDetail.aspx?BookId=SKU-000063139">PDF version of the book</a> (to purchase for $6) and the link did work for me, so if you had trouble with the link in the past you might want to try it again.

Finally, after class we found the author's website here: <a href="http://acts.twu.ca/Library/textbook.htm">http://acts.twu.ca/Library/textbook.htm</a>. Looking through this more thoroughly I found that the Online Abridged Version of the textbook available here is similar but not the same as the print version. For example, for today's reading the Preface is identical, Chapter 8 is shortened, and Chapter 1 is not available at all. This website is a great supplement to the book but, again, I encourage you to pick up the complete version either in paper or PDF.

--Prof Smale]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Class notes 8/31/10</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/08/31/class-notes-83110/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 31 Aug 2010 21:06:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Maura Smale]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Class notes]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="class-notes"><![CDATA[Class notes]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[history]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="history"><![CDATA[history]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[information]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="information"><![CDATA[information]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[innovation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="innovation"><![CDATA[innovation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[lifecycle]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="lifecycle"><![CDATA[lifecycle]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=171</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&#8226; The article I mentioned in class today, <a href="http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/2008/jun/12/the-library-in-the-new-age/">The Library in the New Age</a>, that discusses the 4 innovations in information that I wrote on the whiteboard: writing, the codex (book), printing with movable type, and the internet.

&#8226; <a href="http://www.mkbergman.com/temp-exhibit/">A Timeline of Information Innovation</a>, with lots of details about the history of information. Note that this covers non-electronic information only and doesn't discuss computer- or internet-based information.

&#8226; The video we watched today, <a href="http://www.libraries.psu.edu/content/dam/psul/up/lls/audiovideo/infocycle_2008.swf">The Information Cycle</a>, which explores how different kinds of publications cover the same event.

--Prof Smale]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Growing Opportunities</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/09/01/growing-opportunities/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 01 Sep 2010 08:13:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jessdeng08]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Media]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="media"><![CDATA[Media]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=177</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[By: Jessica Deng

We live in a society where technology is constantly growing and shifting. Everyday new technologies present new and efficient ways for journalists and other media professionals. A constant growth of technology has many benefits in four areas as Pavlik states in the passage.
<ul>
	<li>First, as we all know new technologies often present new and more productive ways for journalists and other media professionals to do their work. Current hand-held gadgets can provide low-cost digital photography and efficient access to navigational services.</li>
	<li>Next, new technologies can turn over the nature of storytelling and media content in potentially positive and engaging ways. In Columbia University, an innovation called the "Situated Documentary" permits news consumers to visit sites of distant past or recent news.</li>
	<li>Third, new technologies have a large significance for the management, structure, and culture of media organizations. A news organization can explore the choice of the "virtual newsroom" which is a newsroom without walls. Pavik described, "It can be established in nearly any community using high- speed wireless Internet access and mobile media." The virtual newsroom can be a representation of a cost-saving innovation in news coverage.</li>
	<li>Finally, the most important opportunity that new technologies can bring forward is the conversion of relationships between news organizations and their audiences, views, regulators, sources, and competitors.</li>
</ul>
New technology is an ever growing expansion and now that we are in the 21st century, journalism and media will be undergoing a lot of changes. Of course when there a lot of positive factors; there are also negative factors but Everyone at any age group, class or status will be or are already in a special position because as technology is growing, our lives are becoming more simple but also sophisticated. Life is made easier with technology.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I agree that there are lots of positive aspects of new technologies, and that our lives can be made easier with technology. What are some examples of the ways technologies have made your life easier, simpler or more sophisticated? What technologies are most important to you?]]></wp:comment_content>

			</item>
		<item>
		<title>Blog Response 1</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/09/02/blog-response-1-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Sep 2010 01:23:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rchen8277]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Blog1]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="blog1"><![CDATA[Blog1]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Ruthless]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="ruthless"><![CDATA[Ruthless]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=180</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As a student in college, it is true that we dont have all the time in the world to read a passage thoroughly enough in order to summarize up what we need in detail. Therefore the term Be Ruthless applies to us, yet compared to high school, we can remember that all we needed to do is look for specific words in a passage to give us an idea in what to write and read. Yet as time goes on, college changes that due to the requirement of more details and to be more careful about how we words things with the idea of plagiarism in mind. Since the passage wants us to determine from our own point of view what are the best ways to read a passage and understand how to take what we need from it, the best idea wouldnt be to just skim or rush through anything.

As a college student even if what we read is boring, I find it required to make sure one does not let any part go cause details in a passage might just be what we need in order to understand what the stand point of the author would be. With experience, I have noticed that when reading something, there are multiple points of view when skipping certain parts of a passage. As long as we only look at a part of the passage that we read, we arent able to see the full view of what the author is trying to persuade us into understanding from his own point of view. Of course, if the material is in a great deal of need and has to be limited to time, it is normal to Be Ruthless and aim for certain parts, but in the end it might not get that reader to understand the full importance of what the author would want to display.

-Richard Chen]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>180</wp:post_id>

		<item>
		<title>Blog Response2</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/09/02/blog-response2/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Sep 2010 01:40:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rchen8277]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[blog2]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="blog2"><![CDATA[blog2]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Response]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="response"><![CDATA[Response]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="technology"><![CDATA[Technology]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Web]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="web"><![CDATA[Web]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=182</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Since the start of the well known existence of the WEB, the reading questions whether or not is it good for the economy and for the writers themselves and how it affects the world. As we know today, publishers have always been tough on what type of materials they want to help publish because of the word money. With the WEB now, it is easier for new writers and those who want to share their thoughts express themselves freely and easier since at this time, technology is booming worldwide.

Because of this existence, it is true the writing community might not like all these unsupervised expressions on thoughts yet without the WEB, we see that there was always a limit to where the writings of today and of the past ends up. One important thing in the WEB is just like what we use in class which is this very Blog. In this blog, we as students can share our thoughts and ideas throughout the world and read the thoughts of others. Of course there are problems with the WEB from glitches to bugs that exist daily, but this doesnt mean that we will abandon every other ways to transfer out thoughts and creations. Just because of the WEB, we as humans arent going to give up writing on paper and pens so that in the future if anything happens to the WEB, we won't depend fully on it. It is always better to have a extra hard/physical draft or everything we post online or on paper.

Subject headings:

Z- Books

ZA-Information Resources

-Richard Chen]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[The phrase "unsupervised expressions" is great. Can you think of any ways in which writers and publishers could benefit from the increasing ability of average folks to express themselves on the web? And do you think that writings on the web are less permanent than in hard copy? (We'll talk more about some of these issues when we talk about preservation in a couple of weeks.)]]></wp:comment_content>
		<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
		<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
		<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
		<wp:comment_user_id>3452646</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
				<wp:comment>
		<wp:comment_id>19</wp:comment_id>
		<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[jessdeng08]]></wp:comment_author>
		<wp:comment_author_email>Jessica.Deng@mail.citytech.cuny.edu</wp:comment_author_email>
		<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
		<wp:comment_author_IP>96.224.24.171</wp:comment_author_IP>
		<wp:comment_date>2010-09-06 03:19:51</wp:comment_date>
		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-09-06 03:19:51</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Well, I like to comment on the line Richard said, "publishers have always been tough on what type of materials they want to help publish because of the word money." I disagree on this part and I am no expert in the publishing business, but in any kind of business, money is not always the reason why certain things do and don't make the cut. Since we are talking about the publishing business, there are other underlying factors as to why publishers are tough on what to publish and what not to publish.  Some of the reasons as to why an item may not be published is because of an insufficient amount of workers and insufficient supply or demand  to meet the needs of a publishing company.]]></wp:comment_content>
		<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>

			</item>
		<item>
		<title>The world is changing </title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/09/02/the-world-is-changing/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Sep 2010 01:52:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[lynn905]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[world]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="world"><![CDATA[world]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/09/02/the-world-is-changing/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In Today' s reading I found out that the world is changing in many way from word of mouth to the world wide web. In Pavlik, John P. From media in the Digital age of New York columbia unisersity press in 2008 talk about new techology and media becoming a uneasy alliance. "In fact media organizations, in particular news organizations, have typically had very small budget." (Pavlik 2). This qoute show that media is had a hard time dealing with new technology and how it alway devolping make it hard to do research, due to the fact their are so many soucres. Even though new technoloy have so many soucres the media refuse to "test the water" (Pavlik 3). This qoute showes that the media rather let other poeple do the dirt work while the media just there scooping from the hard works.
In other Issue, even though they are different they work in an orderly fashion. When New techology incerase in growth and then follows right behind it; is the media who are expanding, even though the media my not be faster as the new techology, their soucres are opening up a whole new world through the world wide web. I've learn that opening up the world wide web is a good thing due to the fact that you have the information right at your finger tips.
Question #1: what if we had everything at our finger tip like books, information, and etc. What would happen to the paper back, would they sit on a shelf collecting dust and be lock away? Maybe that why everything is not at your finger like we think it is; their are many thing you still have to get like in the library or in stores. Question#2: what is daguerreotype? It really not clear to me in the reading?

- Lynn Jean]]></content:encoded>

A daguerreotype was the earliest kind of photograph, dating from the early 1800s. If you have any questions about terms used in any of the readings please feel free to look them up in Wikipedia or a dictionary for more information.]]></wp:comment_content>

		<item>
		<title>Blog Response 2</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/09/02/blog-response-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Sep 2010 06:31:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ssira9018]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Media Technology Virtual Newsroom Navigation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="media-technology-virtual-newsroom-navigation"><![CDATA[Media Technology Virtual Newsroom Navigation]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=188</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Who is a journalist? (p6). In a sense we can all consider ourselves journalists, literally speaking. Whether it means to write a report on current events, being a witness of a tragedy, blog, or simply keeping a journal; we all engage with media, culture and technology every day. In the excerpt <span style="text-decoration:underline;">New Technology and the Media: An Uneasy Alliance</span>, Pavlik provides several suggestions for technology to improve the way media presents itself. Although Im not a huge fan of technology, I found his <strong><em>second suggestion most intriguing</em></strong>. A virtual experience through your own mobile or hand-held equipment. The feature is similar to a video game; it allows you the experience of being a character in the game, while walking around accessing stories (past and present) in the specific location youre standing in. This feature will attract new audience, specially the youth because it provides a sense of adventure and mystery-since every step becomes knowledge of new information. So, not only will they learn but will also enjoy engaging in this activity.

A suggestion I <em><strong>highly disagree</strong></em> with is-suggestion three, a <em>virtual newsroom</em>. A virtual newsroom means there is no setting for news reporters, editors and journalists. They will not come together to organize ideas and publish a clean report. For me-it would mean no more looking forward to watching World News at 7pm. Having a virtual newsroom we also lose creativity and a sense of traditional broadcasting.

I enjoyed this excerpt so much; I decided to search for videos on Media in the New Age. This is the result:

Pavlik, John. (2009). Media in the Digital Age.<em> <span style="text-decoration:underline;">http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LDkcmZ0arSU</span></em>

It helped me understand Pavliks vision. Pavlik addresses the pros and cons of technology and the media. I appreciate his effort to try and change the way of storytelling in order to keep audiences and the world of journalism from becoming archaic.

My question: Will twitter become "journalism" in the future?

-SSIRA9018]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Digital Dilemmas</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/09/03/245/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 03 Sep 2010 10:27:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[hyeongi8309]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[comment]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="comment"><![CDATA[comment]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[online]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="online"><![CDATA[online]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[post]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="post"><![CDATA[post]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=245</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Although new technology affects journalism in many positive ways, it also has many drawbacks. Since the launch of the internet, journalists and ordinary people have been able to gain new information as well as writer their opinions, ideas, and information easily. While not all bad, there are problems that arise from this exchange of information. Due to the large resource of information, it is difficult to determine the necessity of certain information. Also, uncertain information and news articles appear online, many of which may not contain the truth. An example of wrong information found online is are drug websites. The wrong information online harms society <a href="http://abcnews.go.com/Health/story?id=117290&amp;page=1">(ABS NEWS Article)</a>. Another issue stems from the existence of blogs. In South Korea, an actress committed suicide because of the content of her blog and the gossip that took place through the internet. Subsequently, the younger brother of the late actress also committed suicide. After these deaths, the Korean government seta new law in place that requires people to write articles and post replies using their social security numbers <a href="http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1847437,00.html">(An Article about the famous Korean actress Choi Jin-Sil)</a>. In doing so, this allows the government to maintain control of the information that is posted online. Today, it is easy to destroy a person's life easily and lead people to draw wrong conclusions through the internet.

Subject heading:

HX519-550 Communism/socialism in relation to special topics

-Hyeongi Kim]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
		<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>

		<wp:comment_user_id>15975360</wp:comment_user_id>
