		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In the reading the president of hamilton college apologized for his plagiarism, the speeches he may have said over the last nine years were plagiarized at the college he once was in charge of. I wasn't aware that maybe certain speeches that you may have heared over a period of time might have came from someonelse, but reused by another to grab the attention of an audience, who knows just what if famous people or iconic people do so it makes you wonder if whats said by whom ever was it said before and should it stop, and what can we to prevent it from continuing. I believe every philosopher should have his own work and his own speech and words ready to convince the people that, their sincere about what it is they believe in, Eugen Tobin got away almost a decade of using someone else's words and he's now apologizing for it , i dont think thats fair at all to the rightful owner. STEFFON WILSON]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Beyond the word</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/09/30/beyond-the-word/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 30 Sep 2010 04:36:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[lynn905]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[word]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="word"><![CDATA[word]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/09/30/beyond-the-word/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I found this article Plagiarism: a lie of the mind by Maurice Issermanto be very unique. Plagiarism is something that as little kids we never knew of until about three grade or as education went on. "Plagiarism was seen as a transgression against our common intellectual valves, carrying justifiably bad consequences for those guilty of practice". This quote means that plagiarism is shame upon which is a bad thing and you should never do it. I found something that Ms. Issermansaid " usually, when we repeat what others have said or written before us, we don't have the slightest notion that we're doing so, nor do we have any idea to whom we are indebted for the words we recycle". This quote I found it to be so deep, due the fact that we do recycle words, also try to take what authors saying in their text and put it in our own words, but we sometimes fail or just don't quite get the word behind it. In many way, due to the fact itthe words are perfect and there is no way explain fewer or our words are not quite put together to explain what the author means in our own understanding. Ms. Isserman goes beyond the point to even say that plagiarism is black and white, there is more means behind this word then meets the eyes or own understanding.

- Lynn Jean

Subject Headings:

K - Law in general. Comparative and uniformlaw. Jurisprudence

LB - Theory and practice of education

PE - English language]]></content:encoded>

							</item>
		<item>
		<title>On Plagiarism</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/09/30/on-plagiarism/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 30 Sep 2010 05:33:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[bocasman1]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=557</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I believe that everyone who has had to make a speech or write a research paper has struggled with the urge to copy thoughts that reflect our ideas and opinions in words so expertly and eloquently put together that we are sure that we will never be able to attain such level of proficiency. However, we have been taught that to use someone else's ideas without giving the author proper credit is tantamount to stealing and colleges have very serious penalties for those whom are discovered to have engaged in plagiarism.

I have always looked at the rule against plagiarism as one that should be followed (in theory), because I believed that plagiarism was stealing other people's ideas. Of course, this is not to say that I've not used other people's words without giving them proper credit. However, after reading this piece, I come to agree with the author that "it is a bad thing because it takes the place of and prevents learning". After all, we come to school to acquire an education and, as difficult as it may be, we need to struggle through the process of learning to speak with our "own" words because this will empower us for the rest of our lives.

-Rigoberto]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[In this piece the author relates the experience of witnessing the resignation of the president of Hamilton College and how this prompted an examination, among the faculty, of their view of plagiarism. Isserman mentions how conflicted many of his colleagues were because the culprit was not someone far away or unknown, but instead  someone they knew and respected and had done a great deal of good for the institution during the nine years that he led the institution. In the end, the author suggests that the real crime of plagiarism is that the person who engages in it denies himself the opportunity to express his thoughts and ideas and the ability to refine them and improve his intellect in the process.]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>557</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-09-30 01:33:53</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-09-30 05:33:53</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>on-plagiarism</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
								<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key>_edit_lock</wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1285824837]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
				<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[15975414]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
				<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key>jabber_published</wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1285824834]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
				<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key>_wp_old_slug</wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							</item>
		<item>
		<title>Blog Response 6</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/09/30/560/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 30 Sep 2010 06:00:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ssira9018]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Broadcasting]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="broadcasting"><![CDATA[Broadcasting]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Copyrights]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="copyrights"><![CDATA[Copyrights]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Lessig]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="lessig"><![CDATA[Lessig]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Lord Blackstone]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="lord-blackstone"><![CDATA[Lord Blackstone]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=560</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In the short video <span style="text-decoration:underline;">Laws that choke creativity</span>, Harvard professor <em>Larry Lessig</em> addresses the current conflicts of broadcasting and its copyright issues. He creates his core argument of example 2 comparing Lord Blackstone ideology Land protected by trespass law for most of the history of trespass pass law by presuming it protects the land all the way down below and to the indefinite extent upward to conflicts that goagainstit, in this case air planes-whom travel across the country above land that is protected byindividualownership. If original creators are publishing it, then its clear that the public will have access to reproduce and share, not to keep it in a black hole.<span style="font-size:14.1667px;">He argues that copyright should be more lenient and encouraged to the youth since its part of culture, Lessig displays this by showing several video clips of how original copyrighted content was transformed into something entirely new. He stresses that as long as the remixed content is not made for profit than copyright material should be of fair use.</span>

In my opinion all remakes should always credit its original source-ALWAYS! YouTube has a policy that in order to use copyrighted material the creator must be speaking or making comments while the original content is playing-for example video games (although thats still a controversial issue) to add the original content in the remix can only be a minute long. There are several different ways of remixing, Lessing provides examples of <span style="text-decoration:underline;">Jesus singing I will survive and President Bush and Prime Minister Blair lip synching</span>, not only was it hilarious but it does in fact make great sense of entertainment. Even with music, you tubers are collaborating with each other to create parodies of their favorite songs by adding a sense of karaoke, only, with their own lyrics. A recent example of a YouTube remake is <strong>Antoine Dodson</strong>s rant on his sisters rape on the news. His rant was turned into a song by amateur you tube comedians who go by the name <strong>Gregory Brothers</strong>, the catchy song titled <strong>Bed Intruder </strong>has over 27 million hits in less than two months, its available on iTunes too! (People are actually buying it!)

Copy right issues also bring up more controversial subjects like artwork, fashion and new inventions. Although Lessig focused more on video content, it raises the question whether artwork can be imitated into something new. Will this be a remix, remake or plagiarizing someone elses visual ideas?

-SSIRA9018

Subject Heading:

NX-Arts in General

DA-Great Britian]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[People splice up video and audio content all the time. Once it is made into something different from the original it should just be considered a new idea.  It is a new creation. There is a video on youtube.com that is Disney's Alice In Wonderland that someone sliced up and put to music. Now someone has created new art. I totally agree with what Lessig says in the video. I am sure if that person was making money off it Disney would find out and take them to court. The video really isnt something new though because its still clearly from Alice In Wonderland.  It was just "remixed".]]></wp:comment_content>

		<item>
		<title>Plagiarism </title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/09/30/plagiarism-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 30 Sep 2010 12:28:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[gapav]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[intellectual fraud]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="intellectual-fraud"><![CDATA[intellectual fraud]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[plagiarism]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="plagiarism"><![CDATA[plagiarism]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=571</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[

Plagiarism

Plagiarism is defined as a transgression against our common intellectual values, carrying negative consequences for those who perform such bad action. Legally and educationally it could have negative consequences, since Plagiarism is consider a fraud. This theme is completely delicate since it has to concern with the ideas, words, proclamations, inspirations, etc, for these reasons and for our own intellectual convenience everyone should respect other peoples works or at least give some recognition of the people who wrote something. I think that schools, college or any type of institution has to clarify and explain the consequences of plagiarism, in order to create more conscience in peoples minds.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>571</wp:post_id>

		<item>
		<title>The Education for Hire</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/09/30/the-education-for-hire/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 30 Sep 2010 13:34:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rchen8277]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[blog]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="blog"><![CDATA[blog]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[blog6]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="blog6"><![CDATA[blog6]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[post6]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="post6"><![CDATA[post6]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Response]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="response"><![CDATA[Response]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=573</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[On page 10 of the Martin 7 reading, there is a box that consist of the ideas for knowledge which are very accurate on how we as students have to go through during our education. But one point stands out very much to me and it is:

"Scholarly openness and cooperation take second place to
the academic rat race and power struggle which involves
toadying, backstabbing, aggrandisement of resources and
suppression of dissidents".

This part of the reading is very interesting because this topic involves not only the use of power struggling but also the idea of taking ones work as themselves and whats makes another person do it. The thought of scholarly information is a "rat race" tells me that even in writing daily information to writing a book we as students aren't the only ones that have to follow the rules of plagiarism and for a writer one must always be careful of how they store their findings due the the idea of "backstabbing" your work might be lost.

-Rchen]]></content:encoded>

The struggle between education and society, yet we as society always perceive life to be a race or a "rat race" as you put it. We tend to make our papers or writing  sound more complete by try to have the best paper to past the classes or trying to reach a goal that critic may like and etc.  In many ways by doing so we find our self plagiarizing others instead of having an opinion of our own or even if we find a similar viewpoint as the writer we can really express it due to the fact that it says it all. Which in many cases it makes life hard for us because we need to research a certain aspect. 		<title>Plagiarism</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/09/30/plagiarism-3/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 30 Sep 2010 13:53:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jlantigua91]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[illegal]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="illegal"><![CDATA[illegal]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[law]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="law"><![CDATA[law]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[plagiarism]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="plagiarism"><![CDATA[plagiarism]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=575</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Plagiarism a lie of the mind by Maurice Isserman was an article about how plagiarism affected her school and her thoughts on plagiarism. For me plagiarism was really acknowledge my freshman year in high school. The students in my English class were being caught copying and pasting other people work on the internet to do their essays. Just like Maurice I started paying more attention to plagiarism when one of our own got caught. Three students failed the essay because of plagiarism and after that incident my high school began teaching students what was plagiarism and how it was illegal and get you in trouble with the law. This is my second year in City Tech and this year teachers are acknowledging plagiarism more then the previous, i think it's a good idea to explain what is it and how to avoid getting into any trouble. 
   J.Lantigua]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Class notes 9/28/10</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/09/30/class-notes-92810/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 30 Sep 2010 20:02:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Maura Smale]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Class notes]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="class-notes"><![CDATA[Class notes]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[digital]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="digital"><![CDATA[digital]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[format]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="format"><![CDATA[format]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[google]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="google"><![CDATA[google]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[hardware]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="hardware"><![CDATA[hardware]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[paper]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="paper"><![CDATA[paper]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[preservation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="preservation"><![CDATA[preservation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[software]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="software"><![CDATA[software]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=583</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In today's class we discussed preservation.

What is preservation?

<a href="http://lib1201fall2010.files.wordpress.com/2010/09/whiteboard09-28.jpg"><img src="http://lib1201fall2010.files.wordpress.com/2010/09/whiteboard09-28.jpg?w=300" alt="" title="whiteboard09-28" width="300" height="224" class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-584" /></a>

Preservation of paper objects:
&#8226; What's more impt: object or content?
&#8226; Reproduction introduces errors
&#8226; Marginalia and "paratexts": important?
&#8226; Who decides what to preserve?
&#8226; Digitization pros: access, search, fragility
&#8226; Digitization cons: errors, cost, format rot

Preservation of digital objects:
&#8226; Format lifespan: hardware, software
&#8226; Bigger issue w/born digital information
&nbsp; &nbsp; - Produced in great volume
&nbsp; &nbsp; - How to handle it?
&#8226; Managing access to and insuring the preservation of digital info are NOT the same
&#8226; Metadata is critical for findability

We also looked at the Google Books Library Project as a case study that exemplifies some of these issues: <a href="http://books.google.com/googlebooks/library.html">http://books.google.com/googlebooks/library.html</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>583</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-09-30 16:02:03</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-09-30 20:02:03</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>class-notes-92810</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
								<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3452646]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
				<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key>_edit_lock</wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1285876934]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
				<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key>jabber_published</wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1285876928]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
				<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key>_wp_old_slug</wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							</item>
		<item>
		<title>Class notes 9/30/10</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/09/30/class-notes-93010/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 30 Sep 2010 20:16:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Maura Smale]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[academic integrity]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="academic-integrity"><![CDATA[academic integrity]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Class notes]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="class-notes"><![CDATA[Class notes]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[copyright]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="copyright"><![CDATA[copyright]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Creative Commons]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="creative-commons"><![CDATA[Creative Commons]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[ethics]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="ethics"><![CDATA[ethics]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[fair use]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="fair-use"><![CDATA[fair use]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[intellectual property]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="intellectual-property"><![CDATA[intellectual property]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[open access]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="open-access"><![CDATA[open access]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[plagiarism]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="plagiarism"><![CDATA[plagiarism]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[public domain]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="public-domain"><![CDATA[public domain]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=588</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In today's class we discussed information ethics, principally the issues around intellectual property.

Ethical Considerations:
"A wealth of new possibilities awaits those who employ the new digital tools for creating and delivering compelling new content, yet these same tools make it easier than ever to plagiarize and pirate content" (Pavlik, Media in the Digital Age, p. 234).

We began by discussing academic integrity and plagiarism.

&#8226; This article from the New York Times discusses the case of Jayson Blair, a journalist who fabricated and plagiarized news articles while he worked as a Times reporter: <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2003/05/11/national/11PAPE.html">http://www.nytimes.com/2003/05/11/national/11PAPE.html</a>

&#8226; This article from Time Magazine discusses the case of Kaavya Viswanathan, a Harvard sophomore who lost her book contract when it was revealed that she'd plagiarized from another author: <a href="http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1189282,00.html">http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1189282,00.html</a>

For the second half of class we discussed copyright, public domain and fair use:

&#8226; The American Library Association created this digital copyright slider to make it easier to determine whether a work is under copyright: <a href="http://www.librarycopyright.net/digitalslider/">http://www.librarycopyright.net/digitalslider/</a>

&#8226; This copyright expiration flowchart from a law firm's website also provides guidelines on copyright: <a href="http://www.sunsteinlaw.com/practices/copyright-portfolio-development/flowchart.htm">http://www.sunsteinlaw.com/practices/copyright-portfolio-development/flowchart.htm</a>

&#8226; This clever flowchart highlighting some of the differences between purchased movies (with digital rights management) and illegally pirated films: <a href="http://www.geekologie.com/image.php?path=/2010/02/25/piracy-full.jpg">http://www.geekologie.com/image.php?path=/2010/02/25/piracy-full.jpg</a>, while this comic tackles the same issue with downloadable music files: <a href="http://xkcd.com/488/">http://xkcd.com/488/</a>

&#8226; One less restrictive alternative to copyright that many creators are using is Creative Commons licensing: <a href="http://creativecommons.org/">http://creativecommons.org/</a>. The search engine on this website can help you find copyright-free images, sound, and other media to use.

&#8226; Copyright-free doesn't always mean that the creator won't be able to make a living. CASHmusic is essentially a cooperative that uses a subscription or pay-as-you-like model to fund releases from participating musicians. While all releases are available for free download, limited edition or special issues are also available for purchase: <a href="http://cashmusic.org/">http://cashmusic.org/</a>.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Homework for 10/5/10</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/09/30/homework-for-10510/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 30 Sep 2010 20:22:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Maura Smale]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[blog]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="blog"><![CDATA[blog]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[course reading]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="course-reading"><![CDATA[course reading]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[homework]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="homework"><![CDATA[homework]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Homework]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="homework-2"><![CDATA[Homework]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=595</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Beginning next week we will move away from reading response blog posts and into research journal blog posts, which will lead us into the research paper.

I will give you a prompt for all of the research journal blog posts. I'll bring the prompt to class and post it here on the website.

For next Tuesday 10/5, please write your 100-word blog post about any topic we've covered in class so far that you find interesting. What interests you about the topic? Is there anything on this subject youd like to learn more about?

Also for next time, please write 1 comment on any blog post by one of your classmates, and do the reading (Badke Ch. 4 and the article by Dye, full details on the <a href="http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/syllabus/">syllabus</a>).

I'll post and email about our classroom location on Monday. Please let me know if you have any questions.

Have a great weekend!
Prof Smale]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>American Education Rewrite</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/10/02/american-education-not-a-blog-post/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 02 Oct 2010 05:03:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ssira9018]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Critical Teaching]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="critical-teaching"><![CDATA[Critical Teaching]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Education]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="education"><![CDATA[Education]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Public School]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="public-school"><![CDATA[Public School]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Valedictorian Speech]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="valedictorian-speech"><![CDATA[Valedictorian Speech]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=603</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[A few days ago I published a blog post about the American education system and argued how the system has become somewhat corrupt. I permanently deleted the post-so here is my reattempt.

Last week we spoke a little about the valedictorian speech by a student named Erica Goldson from Coxsackie-Athens High school in reference to the class reading T<span style="text-decoration:underline;">he politics of research</span> an excerpt from chapter 7 by <em>Brian Martin. </em>Erica's speech addressed the current issues with the American education system-and several personal experiences throughout her four years.

Erica's courage to speak up was indeed inspiring.

Here is the link to her blog and speech:

<a href="http://americaviaerica.blogspot.com/2010_07_01_archive.html">http://americaviaerica.blogspot.com/2010_07_01_archive.html</a>

In the same sense, I agree with Erica. All throughout the years of elementary, primary and secondary education the only concern for students is passing, going to the next level and graduating with a degree thatcertifies"I am good enough." Its all about studying for an exam the night before but forgetting it all after the exam is over. What we don't realize is that education createsknowledgeand knowledge is something that cannot be bought-in the same sense when we learn without critical thinking, we learn absolutely nothing.

Thats the absence of American education right now; instructorsaren'tteaching students to think critical, their teaching the shortcut-one way of creating a problem, one way of finding the solution. We have calculators to rely on simple math such as integers, for definitions we have access to the internet rather than searching through a real dictionary, for English class we have spark notes and the list goes on. As the years progress, students learn to rely on the shortcut rather than actually trying and putting effort to learn. Now, I'm not blaming everything on teachers, but they do play a huge role on how students learn and perform in exams, projects, classroom participation and even outside of school. Keep in mind that students startthey'reday in school and continue for 8 hours, within these eight hours they should be learning discipline, respect as well as appreciation for learning the curriculum. They should be encouraged to participate in class, ask questions, engage in conversation and express their opinion without being afraid its wrong.

Right now, to be hired as a teacher in elementary, primary and secondary institutions-youre required to have a Masters Degree to be really considered a professional in education. Sadly since the raise of instructor standards-students are failing standard tests more than ever. Why? Would be a question most parents have today. Female teachers are giving assignments, as they are busy painting and filing theyre perfectly cubed nails. Instead of helping students and looking over their work they quietly sit at theyre desk applying the next coat of polish (seen it with my own eyes). Now, I want to make things clear, not all teachers are like this-but in different ways-some are. I also want to make it clear that Im not blaming everything entirely on teachers either.

Another issue is the way public education institutions teach. Public schools are all supposed to teach the same right? Wrong! Our education institution is actually divided into an intellectual hierarchy. There are specialized public schools that filter students from regular schools through entrance exams such as the SSHSAT (Specialized Science High School Admission Test). Even now, there is so much competition for specialized middle schools. Why the competition? There is competition because of reputation of the specific school and their way of teaching and preparing students for the next level. I actually attended a specialized middle school and Im very thankful. Our summer readings consisted works of literature such as Pride and Prejudice (Jane Austin), The Odyssey (Homer) and authors such as John Updike and T.S. Elliot-these are some titles and authors that some of my fellow English classmates heard for the first time in college. I feel that students attending specialized public education institutions have an advantage to accomplishing more than those who attend a regular public school. For example Stuyvesant a specialized public high school receive enormous amounts of funds to continue advanced programs in math and science, a disadvantage for others attending regular public high school. This leads to the question, who will perform best on their SATs without private tutoring? Will it be the student from Stuy, or the student from a regular public high school? The answer is quite obvious.

Public education has become so corrupt because in a sense-not all students are given equal opportunities! Every child is special, they should be taught in way that grasps their attention and makes them want to learn. For example, a subject most students find bore is US history but what they fail to realize is that US History is what shapes us as Americans. History teachers fail to engage students in questioning history, analyzing and providing feedback on how they feel about- for example the American Revolution. If I were to ask one student in a history class or even a student on campus right now who are our four founding fathers?, the response would be silent *crickets chirping*. The problem is the way instructors teach, students are required to copy long lengths of notes from the board, answer a few questions from their textbook, pass a few multiple choice exams and-voila!-the end.

The main point is, students need to learn to appreciate education and in order for them to do is-is through the teachers-they need to perform critical teaching. And I know some will argue that its the students responsibility as well. Think of it this way-its like reading an interesting book till the lights go off, you dont want to stop, you want to find out what comes next, in the same way-teachers need to teach in a way that students want to learn whats next and are able to exercise the way they think along with it, its like an adventure.

In the end educators are forgetting that students are human beings, like Erica said<strong> </strong><strong>I am a human being, a thinker, an adventurer  not a worker.</strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Thank you for posting this link -- I agree that Erica's speech was inspiring. I do feel for teachers, because teaching is a difficult job, and many of the factors that add difficulty are not within their control. But it's clear that many educational strategies used in the past are not effective and engaging. And the unequal access to quality public education is very troubling.

Lots of food for thought here -- thanks, again, for posting!]]></wp:comment_content>

		<item>
		<title>The Combating Online Infringement and Counterfeits Act - Thought everyone would want to read this seeing as how we talk about it everyday</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/10/02/the-combating-online-infringement-and-counterfeits-act-thought-everyone-would-want-to-read-this-seeing-as-how-we-talk-about-it-everyday/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 02 Oct 2010 17:23:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[cbargy]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[censor]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="censor"><![CDATA[censor]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[COICA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="coica"><![CDATA[COICA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[internet]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="internet"><![CDATA[internet]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=610</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In the United States, a new law proposal called The Combating Online  Infringement and Counterfeits Act (COICA) was introduced last week, and  there will be a hearing in front of the Judiciary Committee this  Thursday.

If passed, this law will allow the government, under the command of the  media companies, to censor the internet as they see fit, like China and  Iran do, with the difference that the sites they decide to censor will  be completely removed from the internet and not just in the US.

Please see the following article from the Huffington Post for more information.

<a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/david-segal/stop-the-internet-blackli_b_739836.html" target="_blank">Stop the Internet Blacklist</a>

And if you are a US citizen, please take the time to sign this petition
<a href="http://demandprogress.org/blacklist/" target="blank">DemandProgress.org - Petition to Stop the Internet Blacklist!</a>


<strong>Update:</strong> Also for US citizens, you can email your Senator from the following link and tell him or her your concerns about this bill

<a href="https://secure.eff.org/site/Advocacy?cmd=display&amp;page=UserAction&amp;id=455" target="_blank">Tell Your Senator: No Website Blacklists, No Internet Censorship!</a>

<strong>Update, from EFF's website:</strong> the Senate Judiciary  Committee postponed the scheduled markup of the Internet censorship bill   a fantastic outcome, given that the entertainment industry and their  allies in Congress had hoped this bill would be quickly approved before  the Senators went home for the October recess. Massive thanks to all who  used the EFF Action Center to write to your Senators to oppose this  bill.]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Plagiarism</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/10/03/plagiarism-4/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 04 Oct 2010 00:33:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[cbargy]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[plagiarism]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="plagiarism"><![CDATA[plagiarism]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[students]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="students"><![CDATA[students]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=614</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In the article Isserman states if we are all guilty of straying into that gray area of unintentional plagiarism, haven't we forfeited the right to judge others, including those whose plagiarism may have been more purposeful? I disagree with this. People who plagiarize and make money from it should be held accountable for their actions. We all plagiarize in some way everyday. It is hard not to. Most of the time it is not intentional either. I do agree though with his statement What we do is teach students to develop their own voices and establish ownership of the words they use. And, if and when we in higher education stop doing that, we have pretty well abandoned our justification for existence. I totally agree once students can think for themselves and own up to it, then the teachers job is complete. Then the students become the teachers and it is just a cycle. All we can ask for is for when people speak their minds that it is really their own.]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Agreed. The best way to do that, is through discussion and debates, thats the only way students will be able to exercise their thoughts and therefore they will be able to provide better research on paper and develop new ideas towards the specific subject-more on the plate then those who are copying and not trying to see the facts in a different perspective. I think the conflicts students face most when writing- is starting, ending, or polishing an essay. All the thoughts are scattered and while researching some sentences seem perfect for paraphrasing, because as we discussed in class-what if I feel or think the same way? The brain creates a restriction on any other way to think about that specific sentence you are so dieing to use.  And I agree-most of it is unintentional, but at the end of the day when you don't plagiarize, it feels good to know that every word is your own. ;-)]]></wp:comment_content>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=619</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Hi everyone,

Our new classroom is not ready yet. However, we do need to use the computers for tomorrow's class, so we'll meet in the library's Multimedia Lab. This is the room with computers directly across from the projection room where we've met the past couple of weeks.

Please don't forget that your blogging homework this week includes a comment as well as a 100-word blog post answering the questions I wrote on the board last time. More details are on the course website here:
<a href="http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/09/30/homework-for-10510/">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/09/30/homework-for-10510/</a>

See you tomorrow,
Prof Smale]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Blog Post 7</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/10/04/blog-post-7/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 04 Oct 2010 19:58:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ssira9018]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[internet]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="internet"><![CDATA[internet]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[privacy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="privacy"><![CDATA[privacy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[security]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="security"><![CDATA[security]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Web 2.0]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="web-2-0"><![CDATA[Web 2.0]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=621</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[An issue I would further want to research is, internet privacy. I want to learn whats out there and what I have to do to keep myself safe while surfing online. Recently some tech-geek created a new way toaccurately find someones address through an XXS malicious code-which is able to obtain the MACaddressof your router, which then can be used in Google Maps to find the coordinates of your location-all while you are sitting in you pajamas surfing the web without your notice. I want to learn what is being done to provide security and safety to online web 2.0 users. And I also want to learn more about what happens with tags and why some tagged content on one specific site are viewable on other websites even with a embed restriction-for example a video.

-SSIRA9018]]></content:encoded>

Orwell thought outside of the box and demonstrated theories then combined them into a story.]]></wp:comment_content>

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I think that privacy is also a very interesting topic since we went over in class the many things that count as losing privacy. Yesterday online, a friends told me that the government is planning to start a law to censor things that we place online. The problem with this idea is that from that day forward all of our things that we do online would be read by the government before it can be posted online. Does this also challenge was we have as our own privacy?]]></wp:comment_content>
		<wp:comment_approved>trash</wp:comment_approved>
		<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
		<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
		<wp:comment_user_id>15975228</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
				<wp:comment>
		<wp:comment_id>102</wp:comment_id>
		<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[rchen8277]]></wp:comment_author>
		<wp:comment_author_email>rchen8277@yahoo.com</wp:comment_author_email>
		<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
		<wp:comment_author_IP>96.232.208.173</wp:comment_author_IP>
		<wp:comment_date>2010-10-04 20:40:10</wp:comment_date>
		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-10-05 00:40:10</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I think that privacy is also a very interesting topic since we went over in class the many things that count as losing privacy. Yesterday online, a friends told me that the government is planning to start a law to censor things that we place online. The problem with this idea is that from that day forward all of our things that we do online would be read by the government before it can be posted online. Does this also challenge what we have as our own privacy? 
As for the idea of tagging and tracking people, there are many things in the world that are being developed everyday that it is always a possibility that it can happen to any of us at anytime. My computer always have people try to hack in all the time but because of this, i became more interested in protection and ended up learning certain things to protect my own information from being shared and how to block others from taking things from my household "internet" shared technologies.]]></wp:comment_content>
		<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
		<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
		<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
		<wp:comment_user_id>15975228</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
				<wp:comment>
		<wp:comment_id>119</wp:comment_id>
		<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[bocasman1]]></wp:comment_author>
		<wp:comment_author_email>rlopez1018@aol.com</wp:comment_author_email>
		<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
		<wp:comment_author_IP>69.203.6.19</wp:comment_author_IP>
		<wp:comment_date>2010-10-07 07:12:17</wp:comment_date>
		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-10-07 11:12:17</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[There is no question that there is the potential for our privacy to be compromised every time that we log-on, search for information or post views and opinions about anything on the internet. 
 Unfortunately, many of us have (unwittingly) been willing providers of content about ourselves. In our quest to "express ourselves" to the largest audience possible,  we disclose a great deal of information about our lives and identities. We join social networks, where we proceed to post albums of our photographs, document all our travels and interests, indicate our relationship status, list our favorite movies, foods, report on our displeasure with co-workers, professors or employers, etc.  Yet, we are surprised to discover that some of this information may be "culled" by individual, institutions or the government and used against us.
I am not suggesting that we become Luddites and , simplemindedly, oppose technological progress or be so paranoid that we are constantly looking over our shoulders for the bogeyman who is coming to get us. Instead I propose that we THINK twice before bearing our souls on a medium that is accessible to so many. 
The ability to search for information, to communicate instantly with friends at remote corners of the world, to  "exhibit" our ideas, writings, art, etc. for the whole world to see is of great value, but we must also consider that the more we use and become dependent on these new technologies the closer we come to bringing about the conditions that George Orwell described in 1984.

-Rigoberto]]></wp:comment_content>
		<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
		<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
		<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
		<wp:comment_user_id>15975414</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
			</item>
		<item>
		<title>Research Journal Blog Post 1</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/10/04/research-journal-blog-post-1/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 04 Oct 2010 22:55:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[cbargy]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[copyright]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="copyright"><![CDATA[copyright]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Music]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="music"><![CDATA[Music]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[royalties]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="royalties"><![CDATA[royalties]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=609</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I really liked the discussions on copyrights in different industries. It is a huge deal in the television and music realms. It is a huge part of my life being in the music industry. Its all about royalties these days! I am an electronic music producer and DJ and musician. I use samples everyday. A lot of the samples I create myself but many samples come from stuff others have played or created. Now I could take those samples and chop them up and put effects and filters on them and they would sound nothing like the original. Now is that mine? Do I owe the person who made the original money? Are musicians committing musical plagiarism? You can only play a grouping and patterns of notes so many ways. I would like to do research on musical copyrights. I feel there is a lot more to it these days because we are so digital.

Subject Headings:

M - Music

K1411-1485 - Copyright]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>609</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-10-04 18:55:25</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-10-04 22:55:25</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>research-journal-blog-post-1</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
								<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key>jabber_published</wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1286232928]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
				<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[16096518]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
				<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key>_wp_old_slug</wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
				<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key>_edit_lock</wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1287028871]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
				<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key>tagazine-media</wp:meta_key>

		<item>
		<title>Thoughts to Piracy </title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/10/04/thoughts-to-piracy/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 05 Oct 2010 00:32:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rchen8277]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[blog]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="blog"><![CDATA[blog]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[open access]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="open-access"><![CDATA[open access]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Pirating]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="pirating"><![CDATA[Pirating]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=627</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Pirating is a very big problem at this very moment with the world advancing into a more futuristic point. Like Books, everything else is trying to have a go at the media from music to videos and also to video games. During class i have talked about something i saw online about how pirating old record disks.

"http://www.crunchyroll.com/pulse/music-piracy-before-computers-68394"

I think that this picture shows what we as humans do since the time that interesting things get places into the markets. We see something interesting that we like and we have to obtain it. One of the best ways to do that these days is to directly download everything we want. One point that we had during class that really stood out to me was that we download everything we are interested in and when we like it, we then pay to obtain the real object. I find it fascinating that it is true. Everyone who listens or sees something that fit to their liking at our age would just download it and then after a period of time, if we are still addicted to that same thing, we would end up buying it just like the fans of music that spreads around the world these days.

Subject Headings:

CB- History of Civilization

CD-Diplomatics, Archives, Seals

-rchen]]></content:encoded>

When I was a kid, I recorded songs with radio broadcasting and made a tape and listened and listened. Now, as you mentioned, we just download songs with whatever illegal or paid downloading. Technology makes it a lot easier to listen to music and keep songs. However, since most people download illegally, singers cannot make money as they did a decade ago-when they sold CDs and cassette tapes even though, actually, most people have their songs. I imagine that technology will develop as people actually scan someone's brain, memory, and ideas. If we can do that, there will be another main social issue come out. I think before that (Although there wouldn't happen that) we need to keep a manner in which people respect others idea and properties.]]></wp:comment_content>

		<title>Conference on archiving social media</title>

		<pubDate>Tue, 05 Oct 2010 02:07:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Maura Smale]]></dc:creator>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=634</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Hi everyone,

Given some of our class discussions I thought you might be interested in this short article about a conference last Friday on archiving social media. Sounds like the conference included discussion of issues like privacy and the amount of data being created, among other topics.

<a href="http://chronicle.com/blogPost/The-Future-of-Social-Media/27400/">The Future of Social-Media Archiving</a>

See you tomorrow,
Prof Smale]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>the future of recording labels</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/10/04/the-future-of-recording-labels/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 05 Oct 2010 02:30:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[k3nzo718]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=633</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[since we were given the choice to write on any topic i decided to continue with the recording labels. since i myself am a very big fan of music i am very much interested in knowing what will happen in the future. i want to know what will record labels plan on doingonce they arent able to sell records any more. Will they transfer their sales to the internet? Will they even be able to keep their artist under their label? Will artist just get the hint and leave the record labels so they can persue their careers as free artist. as a prediction on my own terms i feel that artist will leave the companys once they realize that they cant do for them as they could before. due to the fact very few people buy albums any more there is really no point in creating them. more and more people begin to download music under mp3 files leaving cds behind. so im very interested in seeing what the future holds for the recording labels

 kenny]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[My teenagers have mp3 players, ipods and all sorts of appendages hanging from their heads and cemented in their ears. My guess is that you're right on target with your blog. Anywhere we go that's just how they listen to music and whatever they desire that they downloaded at home or school or from their friends. It's their choice. I listen to the news on the radio and TV; but they seem to have made up their own mind and listen to whatever they want. I depend on whatever station comes in clear on the radio and whatever CNN, BBC, FOX or local networks decide to broadcast. Half the time I'm talking to thin air because they tune me out with those earphones tucked and pushed into their external auditory canals! 		<wp:comment_id>118</wp:comment_id>
		<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[cbargy]]></wp:comment_author>
		<wp:comment_author_email>cbargy@gmail.com</wp:comment_author_email>
		<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
		<wp:comment_author_IP>173.52.246.151</wp:comment_author_IP>
		<wp:comment_date>2010-10-07 02:55:45</wp:comment_date>
		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-10-07 06:55:45</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I dont think CDs will die. Even though you can throw music on to a USB drive and play it that way it is not going to sound as good as a CD. Music gets compressed so much and you loose a lot when you make it digital. You would have to make files so large that depending on how long the song is could be up to 1GB per song.  Sound engineers are encouraged to tune sound systems to actual pressed CDs because of the quality. Sample rates and and bit rates can only be so high though too.  MP3 players are only around for convenience. It is just so easy to pop those buds in your ears and go. It is very bad for your ears to be honest. I always like to have physical discs though because its the fail safe hard copy backup. I have DVD back ups of all my music which is well over 500GB. You just never know when technology will fail.]]></wp:comment_content>

			</item>
		<item>
		<title>Thoughts on Blogging &amp; Non-Text Media</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/10/04/thoughts-on-blogging-non-text-media/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 05 Oct 2010 02:47:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jessdeng08]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[blog]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="blog"><![CDATA[blog]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[blogging]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="blogging"><![CDATA[blogging]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Media]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="media"><![CDATA[Media]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=631</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As most of you know I am an active blogger and writer but after attending this class so far,it's made me wonder, Where did Blogging come from? and When did it first start? I've had multiple blogs before and I've started blogging since I was 14 but never wondered or thought where did blogging come from? and all these questions about the history of blogging and what is this drive that makes people want to blog more &amp; more and what makes people create blogs in the first place?

I want to find out and ask my fellow friends as well why is blogging so important and when did they start. As for non-text media, I'd like to know what kind of importance do non-text media issue? The different types of non-text media, the advantages/disadvantage and how it's distributed. There are questions unanswered and I hope that I will be able to conduct research and find out on the history of blogging and non-text media.

SUBJECT HEADING:

ZA - Information resources (General)

MT  Instruction and study

- Jessica Deng]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>631</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-10-04 22:47:00</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-10-05 02:47:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>thoughts-on-blogging-non-text-media</wp:post_name>

		<item>
		<title>I Wanna Have Critical Mind</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/10/04/i-wanna-have-critical-mind/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 05 Oct 2010 02:49:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[hyeongi8309]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=642</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As I mentioned before, today, there is much information, so it is not easy to research. Technology makes it a lot easier to find information but also we need to improve research skills and develop critical mind when we find information. Although we discussed about those issues, I still don't know how to keep critical aspects in my mind. I am, sometimes, convinced by wrong information when I read tricky issues such as science, political, and or even entertainment gossip. Indeed, it is really hard to figure out which information is true or not. There are some issues about arguing about internet posts. <a href="http://www.stanforddaily.com/2010/09/27/korean-pop-star-battles-attacks-on-stanford-record/">A famous singer in South Korea graduated Stanford university with a nice grade in a short amoung of time</a>--he finished his master and bachelor degree in 3years and half year but some online blog suspected his diploma of being false and the rumor that he didn't actually graduated from Stanford University is spread out whole country. And many people started to believe the conspicuous (some people still don't believe his diploma). And, now, both the singer and the bloggers are suing each other and Korean main broadcast company, MBC, made a documentary about his issue and problem online posts. Through this issue, I was confused which one is truth and both side showed many documents and papers that support their own side that make people confused. And I want to build a critical view and know how to get critical mind.

-Hyeongi Kim]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_author_IP>173.52.248.11</wp:comment_author_IP>
		<wp:comment_date>2010-10-06 15:32:37</wp:comment_date>
		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-10-06 19:32:37</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[As you mentioned the issues with finding accurate information-it follows the same concept of believing conspiracy theories or not. There is a batch full of information floating around the web but like you said not all information is true. Media does the same thing, they publish news that society wants to hear or what they want society to believe in. The answer to a critical mind, is being able to critically think hence we must all be open minded to every information we process. We must learn to see everything in two perspectives, only then can we make a conclusion on which we want to believe in. Although for research papers, this might be a little more difficult-but for now we can rely on scholarly sources (its better then nothing). Btw I enjoy reading your posts, specially how you relate most of them to Korea. :)]]></wp:comment_content>

I also understand that we should be careful when we need information about science, politics, religion, etc; in this case I use internet and library resources to confirm such information. I definitely suggest and encourage everyone to look up for more analog or digital resources in order to obtain accurate information.]]></wp:comment_content>

Technology makes the research lots of the technology easier but at the same time we need to know improve our research skills. The aspect the technology makes our life easier but indeed it affecting our lives. The Most of the time we just think about the advantage of technology but we dont thing about the down part. All the little consequences, which could take serious part of our lives. So I think we should discuss more about the technology and how it effecting our lives]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>What Has Society Come To?</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/10/05/what-has-society-come-to/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 05 Oct 2010 12:32:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[lynn905]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Society]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="society"><![CDATA[Society]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=652</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Today In class we talk about how plagiarism and how there are some gray areas to it, mean that it not only "black and white" - according toMs. MauricIsserman author of Plagiarism: a lie of the mind. The reason for this gray areas due to the fact you can get away with and some you can't. For example my Professor gave the class a Plagiarism/Academic Misconduct Quiz and check this out!
Do you think this is Plagiarism or it ok to do? (P/ Ok)
____ I got my friend to read my paper and write down other quotes that would help support my argument.
The answer is_P_beacuse the reader is doing the work for the writer, but yet the instructors may assign students such tasks as part of Peer Response work which makes this a gray area.
In class I found Copyright very interestingand howtheir are certain laws saying that it ok to use the material that have been copyright for over a number of years and that it not ok to use the material at all whatsoever. The Example that the class engagein The Mickey Mouse law and how they would write people up for using there Mickey Mouse log. One of my college peers pose a question referringto The Mickey Mouse law. He said: "what if someone had a tattoo of Mickey Mouse tattooon their arm would they start giving summing about having their log on the person arm. That crazy how society may even go that far to have a law in posed. The question that reminds in the air for me is that what ok to have for yourself and what not ok, due to the fact society is being censure and have laws for everything.

-Lynn Jean

Suject Headings:

NC - Drawing. Design. Iullstration

J - General legislative and executive papers]]></content:encoded>

								<wp:comment>
		<wp:comment_id>110</wp:comment_id>
		<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[bocasman1]]></wp:comment_author>
		<wp:comment_author_email>rlopez1018@aol.com</wp:comment_author_email>
		<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
		<wp:comment_author_IP>69.203.6.19</wp:comment_author_IP>
		<wp:comment_date>2010-10-05 09:50:20</wp:comment_date>
		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-10-05 13:50:20</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I think that the point of copyrights is to protect the intellectual property of the creators of written words, images, paintings, etc. We may find it ridiculous that the Image of Mickey mouse is protected, but how would we like it if someone took an image that we created ( photograph, drawings,etc.) and proceeded to use it in a manner that you did not approve of, say a pornographic  cartoon strip or movie using your character.   The fact that your product is successful and recognized by millions should not invalidate our right to ownership.  On the contrary, it should entitle you to reap the benefits of your creativity. 

Rigoberto]]></wp:comment_content>

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Hyeongi, your question about the writing center is a good one. I encourage everyone to go to the writing center and work with the tutors there (I'll announce this in class, too). It's so valuable to have someone else proofread our work. The tutors should help point out weaknesses in grammar and writing, not simply fix them, though. Let me know if you experience otherwise!]]></wp:comment_content>

It's like saying that little kids who look up to Mickey for whatever reasons, can't even trace over pictures for their rooms. the sad thing is that many people dont know whats going on. I read in an article that somethings may not say that it is copy right but in fact really is. In this day and age many things are and we aren't aware. i understand people want to be known for their work but sometimes are taken a little too far.

		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I agree with your opinion on plagiarism. Indeed, it is really hard to
judge which instance is plagiarism or not. The quiz that the professor
gave us was so interesting. Actually, I got wrong answers on some of
them. As an international student, I always go to the writing center
at school and check my essay before I hand in; however, I never
thought it was plagiarism since those writing was my opinion and
ideas, I thought it was ok. Yet, I don't still believe my writing
skills so I surely need someone who help me to fix my writing. But, if
it is plagiarism what am I going to do?]]></wp:comment_content>

			</item>
		<item>
		<title>Thoughts on Plagiarism</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/10/05/thoughts-on-plagiarism/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 05 Oct 2010 12:53:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[brooklynr]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[plagiarism]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="plagiarism"><![CDATA[plagiarism]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=651</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Last week in class we discussed a lot of interesting facts from copy writing to plagiarism.What really caught my attention was plagiarism. To me plagiarism was only thought of as copying other people work as your own. I never realized that having a friend read one of my papers and adding quotes to help my paper is actually plagiarism. The interesting reason why it is, because I myself am not actually writing these quotes. which means the reader is doing the work for me and isn't my thoughts. So someone might and could say that I handed in my readers' paper. This is interesting because many people have read my papers and wrote things to include. Ididn'tknow this could me be seen as plagiarism.

subject Headings:

ZA- information resources

AC Collections. Series. Collected works]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>651</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>thoughts-on-plagiarism</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>

								<wp:comment>
		<wp:comment_id>128</wp:comment_id>
		<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Maura Smale]]></wp:comment_author>
		<wp:comment_author_email>msmale@citytech.cuny.edu</wp:comment_author_email>

		<wp:comment_author_IP>24.186.96.46</wp:comment_author_IP>

		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-10-10 01:33:07</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[It's definitely a fine line: essentially it's the difference between suggesting changes to a paper and actually making the changes for someone else. But it's definitely *not* an argument against peer review -- having someone else read our work can be so helpful, and as long as we make sure to make the changes ourselves we'll stay on the right side of that line.]]></wp:comment_content>
		<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>

		<item>
		<title>The shaping of knowledge</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/10/05/the-shaping-of-knowledge/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 05 Oct 2010 13:16:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[bocasman1]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/10/05/the-shaping-of-knowledge/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We have covered a number of interesting topics in this class. However, I believe that the discussion of critical thinking, prompted by Martin's piece, is the one that should have the greatest impact on all readers. I say this because  the article it points to the importance of our understanding that our knowledge of any subject is shaped by the information that we receive regarding that subject and that that information is made available to us by "gatekeepers" who determine what research is funded and whose interests are furthered by the propagation of this information. The result if this is that much of what we read is nothing more than propaganda intended to sway our opinion in one direction or another. 

History is replete of examples of how the masses have been manipulated into advocating, defending and even going war over issues that they barely understand and that are not in their best interests. Nevertheless, these people are convinced that the positions they hold are based on irrefutable facts. "Facts" that, upon careful intellectual or physical examination, would prove to be untenable. Here are but a few examples: 
1. The preamble of our constitution states " we hold these facts to be self evident, that all men are created equal...." YET, the majority of the people had no problem with the institution of slavery (which flies in the face of the statement on equality and could not be held if LOGICAL/CRITICAL thinking were applied. 
2. We launched a war against Iraq based on sketchy (often, manufactured) evidence and the strong belief by most of our populace that Iraq supported Al Queda and had something to do with the attack on the World trade center. Anyone who had studied history of our relationship with Iraq and analysed the facts critically would have been unconvinced by the flimsy connections that were made by those arguing in favor of war.
3,.The people running around claiming that President Obama was not born in the United States and, therefore ineligible to be President (not tho mention their belief that he is a Muslim). Has anyone stopped to think how elaborate a ruse would have had to be planned and worked-on for over FORTY years to get him accepted into the "right" colleges, elected to the Senate, selected as presidential candidate by the Democratic Party, and have him elected president at a time when there is an explosion of Muslim fundamentalism around the world. 

Anyone who can THINK would conclude that it is necessary to have alternate sources of information and NEVER assume that anything that we're reading is completely true or that it is being reported in a "fair and balanced" manner. If we take anything from this course and the time we spend in a university it ought to be the knowledge that there are entire organizations dedicated to "manufacturing consent" and that we should develop critical thinking skills so that we may not fall prey to their lies and fabrications.

-Rigoberto
  
]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>657</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_author_IP>24.186.96.46</wp:comment_author_IP>

		<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-10-10 01:36:44</wp:comment_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Critical thinking is a big part what we're about in this course, you are right. We've discussed it on and off throughout the semester but will return to it in a big way in a week or so when we work on evaluating information. The "birther" movement of those who believe that the President is not an American citizen is a great example -- we discussed that in this class last semester, actually.]]></wp:comment_content>

		<title>More on knowledge</title>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/10/05/more-on-knowledge/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I think that it is obvious in my previous posting why I am interested in critical thinking. However, we were asked to indicate the following:
1. Why am I interested in the subject?
    I believe that too many people respond like sheep and follow/believe whatever they're told. I wonder what can be done to get more individuals to think.
2.  I would like to know why so many people are so gullible.]]></content:encoded>

To your answer that "we  respond like sheep", the reason for that is some of us don't take the lead, we rely on what on other people's ideas. which are like barriers to our brain. In many cases that why professors learn to let students chosen their own topic as long it relate to the course and what have been discuss in class, for they know we are the future of tomorrow the leaders from the time we walk through the doors till the time we graduate. Their job is to inspire us to be specula to many things, be creative which is the key to inspiration of new changes to a better society impacting it for the good and not negative. I believe the reason for this is  that we as society fail to question why this is that, and what the reason for picking this. That the reason my we are so gullible in a sense. 		<item>
		<title>Class notes 10/5/10</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/10/06/class-notes-10510/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 06 Oct 2010 16:16:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Maura Smale]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Class notes]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="class-notes"><![CDATA[Class notes]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[folksonomy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="folksonomy"><![CDATA[folksonomy]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=734</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In class we discussed metadata, taxonomies and folksonomies.

&#8226; Library of Congress Classification Online (<a href="http://www.loc.gov/catdir/cpso/lcco/">http://www.loc.gov/catdir/cpso/lcco/</a>): an outline of the Library of Congress classification system in use by most academic libraries. (The other major classification system is the Dewey Decimal System, used by public and K-12 school libraries.)

&#8226; Cookery is Dead (<a href="http://jenna.openflows.com/lcsh/2010/week22/cookingatlast">http://jenna.openflows.com/lcsh/2010/week22/cookingatlast</a>: Jenna Freedman's (a librarian at Barnard College) blog post about the Library of Congress's recent decision to replace the subject heading Cookery with Cooking.

Here are the powerpoint notes from the first part of the class:
<a href='http://lib1201fall2010.files.wordpress.com/2010/10/lib1201_10051.pdf'>LIB1201_1005</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>

		<item>
		<title>Classroom for Thursday 10/7</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/10/06/classroom-for-thursday-107/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 07 Oct 2010 00:28:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Maura Smale]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Announcements]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="announcements"><![CDATA[Announcements]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[classroom]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="classroom"><![CDATA[classroom]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=582</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Hi everyone,

Our new classroom is still not ready, so we'll be in the library's Multimedia Lab again.

See you tomorrow,
Prof Smale]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>582</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-10-06 20:28:44</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-10-07 00:28:44</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>classroom-for-thursday-107</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
								<wp:postmeta>

		<item>
		<title>Rearch Mechanics</title>
		<link>http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/2010/10/06/rearch-mechanics/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 07 Oct 2010 02:20:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Rehana]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://lib1201fall2010.wordpress.com/?p=741</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In this chapter Badke describe what is database and how to search database with keywords and hierarchies. A database is a collection of something or information that is organized and by order. Database make research easier because it set up with alphabetically and organized search with the data we need . He gives two mechanisms of research database : the key word searching and the hierarchies. most of us familiar with the key words searching . the key word searching is type exactly word which you want to find out in a database. with the key word searching , we get the information about which we type. sometimes we don't get what we looking for . Because there are lots of similar database huge so we need to be specific with our key words. Badke give very useful ideas for key words searching such as using synonyms, and,or ,* ?.

and Hierarchiers.i'm confused about this technical.]]></content:encoded>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[course reading]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="course-reading"><![CDATA[course reading]]></category>
